revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-05 01:07:40.000000000', 'message': 'Use admin context to retrieve metadata ports in NVP plugin

The port that connects the router and the metadata
network is created with admin context, so use the
elevated one.

Change-Id: Idd416fe0841f6aea80da3a3b66a80a451e0360fd
Closes-Bug: 1220877
'}]
commit_message:
Use admin context to retrieve metadata ports in NVP plugin

The port that connects the router and the metadata
network is created with admin context, so use the
elevated one.

Change-Id: Idd416fe0841f6aea80da3a3b66a80a451e0360fd
Closes-Bug: 1220877

commit_message:
Implementing heat as an optional provisioning system

* Adds a template
* Adds create and delete functionality

implements blueprint heat-integration

Change-Id: I64b524c589620fb81867bee1ea5dd69ea9017132

I'm not sure I understand why this belongs in DevStack. It's a) for old versions of a hypervisor and b) very specific to nova-compute. Shouldn't it be included with the driver that needs it?"}, {'account_id': 7629, 'date': '2013-08-19 22:47:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

1) if you are working in devstack and you are working on old versions of the hypervisor, you'll need it.

2) Where else would I put this? When else is a developer going to hit this bug and need a solution?

I really am open to suggestions."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-08-21 19:35:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Shawn:

2) with the driver that requires it?  Is this a DevStack-only problem?'}, {'account_id': 7629, 'date': '2013-08-23 20:05:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Well, I didn't see any other CLI tools mixed in with the nova-compute code.

This would be something you would absolutely need when you ran devstack. I can't imagine I'll get this in under nova/cmd and I really doubt it belongs in nova/virt/vmwareapi (at least I wouldn't want it there since it would clutter the package.)

It's not great, but I'm just looking for ways to get this into people's hands."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-08-23 21:28:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I guess my point was "I'm running the vmware hypervisor via packages and not using DevStack.  Do I need this then?"'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-08-24 08:06:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I think that this should maybe be part of the code in nova. How about nova/tools/vmware (this is similar to nova/tools/xenserver).
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-09-04 11:03:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm with gary, I'm not sure this belongs in devstack."}, {'account_id': 7629, 'date': '2013-09-05 15:20:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Abandoned

I'm going to put this in the driver as part of:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/vmware-driver-configuration-validator-module"}]

commit_message:
vmware - vsphere v5.0 - WSDL cleanup script.

fixes bug 1211853

When using DevStack with vSphere 5.0, it may be
necessary to locally cache the WSDL locally to
the nova-compute driver for vCenter or ESXi.
This will allow an administrator to modify their
local copy of the WSDL to be more easily parsed
by the driver.

Change-Id: I911e0644dc062ac1ffb6afba294eacb8f54bf580

[{'created': '2013-08-08 16:25:22.000000000', 'message': 'xenapi: ovf - decompress image stream

This change implements the last bit of the image download.
get_stream_funct_for will return a different streaming function if it is
used on images with ovf container format.

related to blueprint xenapi-supported-image-import-export

Change-Id: Ibb7a54261b50f73100f4ab4acd59d8e7cd2901a0
'}, {'created': '2013-08-08 22:34:43.000000000', 'message': 'xenapi: ovf - decompress image stream

This change implements the last bit of the image download.
get_stream_funct_for will return a different streaming function if it is
used on images with ovf container format.

related to blueprint xenapi-supported-image-import-export

Change-Id: Ibb7a54261b50f73100f4ab4acd59d8e7cd2901a0
'}, {'created': '2013-08-22 18:23:46.000000000', 'message': 'xenapi: ovf - decompress image stream

This change implements the last bit of the image download.
A class, GlanceImage was created to support caching of glance
operations. This object is used by higher-level objects, RawTGZImage and
RawImage, which provide the get_virtual_size and get_stream_func
operations for download.

RawTGZImage uses the underlying glance image stream as a tar file. As
the client asks for the image size, the first tar info is read, and
cached (_RawTGZInfoReadState).  Subsequent calls for size are safe, and
will not read the stream. The client can ask the image to write its
contents to a file (stream_to).  This will result in writing the targz
file entry to the specified file.  The RawTGZImage considered to be
closed after its read, and will raise exceptions (_RawTGZFinishedState).

related to blueprint xenapi-supported-image-import-export

Change-Id: Ibb7a54261b50f73100f4ab4acd59d8e7cd2901a0
'}, {'created': '2013-08-28 14:45:44.000000000', 'message': "xenapi: support raw tgz image download

Support the download of raw tgz images. The image's size is retrieved
by reading the first tarinfo from the stream.

related to blueprint xenapi-supported-image-import-export

Change-Id: Ibb7a54261b50f73100f4ab4acd59d8e7cd2901a0
"}, {'created': '2013-08-31 12:15:12.000000000', 'message': "xenapi: support raw tgz image download

Support the download of raw tgz images. The image's size is retrieved
by reading the first tarinfo from the stream.

related to blueprint xenapi-supported-image-import-export

Change-Id: Ibb7a54261b50f73100f4ab4acd59d8e7cd2901a0
"}]
commit_message:
xenapi: support raw tgz image download

Support the download of raw tgz images. The image's size is retrieved
by reading the first tarinfo from the stream.

related to blueprint xenapi-supported-image-import-export

Change-Id: Ibb7a54261b50f73100f4ab4acd59d8e7cd2901a0

subject: xenapi: refactor - extract image_utils

commit_message:
xenapi: refactor - extract image_utils

Extract GlanceImage and RawImage. With these abstractions in place, it's
much more easier to implement support for new container and image
formats.

related to blueprint xenapi-supported-image-import-export

Change-Id: Iffe363a40af046c5c2841ecd1a981c5672eca584

'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-14 11:34:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Why a new create tar binary? Aren't there CLI tools to do that already?"}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-08-14 13:12:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Joe - The issue is, that we want to create a targz stream from a device file's contents. I found no way to tell tar to include the device file's contents. I always ended up with a targz, and a block device file inside.

A separate command was created, because:
 - Doing it in the same process seemed to be hard:
   - for creating a tar file, you need to provide an object, that is an output stream (its write method will be called by the library), whereas glance requires an input stream (it will call the read() method on the passed in object). So the workflow would looked a bit ugly:
     - if a read() called, feed some bytes to targz, until it produced enough bytes by calling the write() method.
     - pass back those bytes as a result of read.
 - tarfile does not have a public interface, that could be written, so the above mentioned method would have required to include some tarfile internal code (bad).
 - extra benefit - the utility could be used to create image"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-14 14:30:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I am uncomfortable with adding a new binary for such a minor thing, especially so late in havava development.  I am not sure what a better alternative is at this moment (written from a tiny device) but I am sure there is one.'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-08-14 15:35:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Joe - It's an important change for xenserver, as this is the way we could do image import/export in a supported way. Maybe if the script were renamed, that would help? Why can't we add a script?"}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-08-14 17:02:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Maybe this approach would work?

 rpipe, wpipe = os.pipe()
 rfile = greenio.GreenPipe(rpipe, 'rb', 0)
 wfile = greenio.GreenPipe(wpipe, 'wb', 0)

 pool = eventlet.GreenPool()
 pool.spawn(produce_targz_stream, wfile)
 pool.spawn(upload_to_glance, rfile)

 pool.waitall()"}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-08-14 21:37:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Work In Progress

Setting this to work in progress, I would like to try greenthreads.'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-08-15 13:50:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-08-15 13:53:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-08-15 14:37:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-20 15:46:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: (2 inline comments)

Mate:

Overall this looks good.

For small setups/test-environments this seems like an acceptable solution.

Though, I'm worried that streaming (very-large) images through the compute-manger is not going to scale up very well? Are you guys seeing good performance here? Have you tried using this driver with a large number of concurrent snapshots?

Just for the sake of discussion, we at Rackspace are going in a slightly different direction: we're trying to eliminate any unnecessary hops for the image on its way to the object-store.

For this reason, we use the dom0 plugins (eliminate need to stream data through compute manager) and are using a direct-to-swift plugin (eliminates need to stream through glance).

We don't have numbers yet on how much faster this alternative approach is (we're working on it), but we expect it to be at least somewhat faster, and to scale out to large number of concurrent snapshots."}, {'account_id': 8430, 'date': '2013-08-20 17:31:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

Looks good.'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-08-21 11:02:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (3 inline comments)

Thanks for the comments, I will push a new patch.'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-08-21 11:02:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Work In Progress

Amending patch according to the comments.'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-08-22 10:17:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-08-22 10:43:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

@Rick:
> Rick Harris wrote:
> Patch Set 5: (2 inline comments)
> 
> Mate:
> 
> Overall this looks good.
> 
> For small setups/test-environments this seems like an acceptable solution.
Yes, that's the goal, to be able to use XenServer without plugins. The long
term goal would be to make xapi able to communicate with glance.
> 
> Though, I'm worried that streaming (very-large) images through the
> compute-manger is not going to scale up very well? Are you guys seeing good
> performance here? Have you tried using this driver with a large number of
> concurrent snapshots?
We haven't made performance measurements. Are you suggesting one base image
with several snapshots, and exporting those snapshots in parallel?

> 
> Just for the sake of discussion, we at Rackspace are going in a slightly
> different direction: we're trying to eliminate any unnecessary hops for the
> image on its way to the object-store.
Yes, that's the medium - long term goal here as well. If you are interested,
jump -in to the conversation here:
https://lists.xenserver.org/sympa/arc/xs-devel/2013-08/msg00063.html
I would really appreciate your input.

> 
> For this reason, we use the dom0 plugins (eliminate need to stream data
> through compute manager) and are using a direct-to-swift plugin (eliminates
> need to stream through glance).
> 
> We don't have numbers yet on how much faster this alternative approach is
> (we're working on it), but we expect it to be at least somewhat faster, and
> to scale out to large number of concurrent snapshots.

@Cristopher:
I switched over to context managers, so that we don't have to worry about closes."}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-08-22 10:46:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

 term goal would be to make xapi able to communicate with glance.

"}, {'created': '2013-08-22 10:17:50.000000000', 'message': 'xenapi: through-dev raw-tgz image upload to glance

Upload tgz compressed raw disk images to glance using supported xapi
interfaces.

At the moment, image upload could only be done with dom0 plugins.
These plugins are not supported by Citrix. This change adds an alternate
method, which only uses supported interfaces:

 - Attach the virtual disk to be uploaded to the nova domU as a block
   device.
 - nova reads the block device, and creates a tar.gz stream.
 - glance client reads the stream, and updates the image.

In order to use this functionality, in nova.conf, you need to specify:

    xenapi_image_upload_handler =
    nova.virt.xenapi.image.vdi_through_dev.VdiThroughDevStore

DocImpact

implements blueprint xenapi-supported-image-import-export

Change-Id: I7541b8fef3a55939179b6355ed178146c1f8f9d6
'}, {'created': '2013-08-27 16:33:00.000000000', 'message': "xenapi: through-dev raw-tgz image upload to glance

Upload tgz compressed raw disk images to glance using supported xapi
interfaces.

At the moment, image upload could only be done with dom0 plugins.
These plugins are not supported by Citrix. This change adds an alternate
method, which only uses supported interfaces:

 - Attach the virtual disk to be uploaded to the nova domU as a block
   device.
 - nova reads the block device, and creates a tar.gz stream. The tar.gz
   stream contains only one file, disk.raw, with the block device's
   contents.
 - glance client reads the stream, and updates the image.

In order to use this functionality, in nova.conf, you need to specify:

    xenapi_image_upload_handler =
    nova.virt.xenapi.image.vdi_through_dev.VdiThroughDevStore

DocImpact

implements blueprint xenapi-supported-image-import-export

Change-Id: I7541b8fef3a55939179b6355ed178146c1f8f9d6
"}]
commit_message:
xenapi: through-dev raw-tgz image upload to glance

Upload tgz compressed raw disk images to glance using supported xapi
interfaces.

At the moment, image upload could only be done with dom0 plugins.
These plugins are not supported by Citrix. This change adds an alternate
method, which only uses supported interfaces:

 - Attach the virtual disk to be uploaded to the nova domU as a block
   device.
 - nova reads the block device, and creates a tar.gz stream. The tar.gz
   stream contains only one file, disk.raw, with the block device's
   contents.
 - glance client reads the stream, and updates the image.

In order to use this functionality, in nova.conf, you need to specify:

    xenapi_image_upload_handler =
    nova.virt.xenapi.image.vdi_through_dev.VdiThroughDevStore

DocImpact

implements blueprint xenapi-supported-image-import-export

Change-Id: I7541b8fef3a55939179b6355ed178146c1f8f9d6

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-04 19:45:11.000000000', 'message': 'Refresh network info cache for secgroups

Before updating security group rules, we need to make sure that
the info cache is up-to-date. Without this source groups are not
updated properly. This was a regression introduced in commit
85aac04704350566d6b06aa7a3b99649946c672c which fixed a potential
DOS using source groups.

Fixes bug 1216720

Change-Id: I6b5115df53f2e159ea506ef966cd49cedd35f83d

commit_message:
Refresh network info cache for secgroups

Before updating security group rules, we need to make sure that
the info cache is up-to-date. Without this source groups are not
updated properly. This was a regression introduced in commit
85aac04704350566d6b06aa7a3b99649946c672c which fixed a potential
DOS using source groups.

Fixes bug 1216720

Change-Id: I6b5115df53f2e159ea506ef966cd49cedd35f83d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-19 20:48:06.000000000', 'message': 'Call _post_downgrade_### after downgrade migration is run

Fixes bug 1195470

Tests are currently only run after a upgrade during the database migration
unit tests and never during a downgrade. This change calls an optional
_post_downgrade_### method after running the downgrade migration to allow
it to be tested as well.

Change-Id: I592424b464b91c2be9e253402986e673ce33c8d0
'}]
commit_message:
Call _post_downgrade_### after downgrade migration is run

Fixes bug 1195470

Tests are currently only run after a upgrade during the database migration
unit tests and never during a downgrade. This change calls an optional
_post_downgrade_### method after running the downgrade migration to allow
it to be tested as well.

Change-Id: I592424b464b91c2be9e253402986e673ce33c8d0

What is the impact of setting all those values to zero? The host will not be a candidate for scheduling instances I assume? It seems odd to expose a host with zero CPUs, and a blank processor vendor. Are these values that are timing-sensitive, in that they'll show up in a few minutes after startup or something?"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-09-03 14:37:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

When the values are not set the virt driver terminates with an exception.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-09-03 18:55:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yeah, I got that.

Also, isn't this a dup of I75b1f069e0b27eebd63c280e36533354c04e246a ?"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-09-03 19:00:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

No, they are 2 different problems. This is when the host statistics returned are partial and may have missing data.
The other is when no Host or actaull "" is returned for the host.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-09-05 15:05:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

This is now part of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/43621/'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-28 08:44:35.000000000', 'message': 'VMware: validate summary fields exist prior to accessing

The data returned by HostConfigSummary may have some fields
that are not set by the backend. The patch validates that the
fields are set. If they are not set then a default value is
returned instead.

Fixes bug: 1217541

Change-Id: I4ea99141027274a9173d7f40ba5fb88bd5aa8fe9
'}]
commit_message:
VMware: validate summary fields exist prior to accessing

The data returned by HostConfigSummary may have some fields
that are not set by the backend. The patch validates that the
fields are set. If they are not set then a default value is
returned instead.

Fixes bug: 1217541

Change-Id: I4ea99141027274a9173d7f40ba5fb88bd5aa8fe9

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-05 14:06:58.000000000', 'message': "Allow block devices without device_name

This patch removes the check in the API that prevented having block
devices without 'device_name' and makes the compute manager capable of
guessing those names.

Before creating the instance, the manager will check each one of the
block devices that should be attached and verify that all of them have a
device_name assigned. If any of them doesn't, it will try to guess a
valid name using the method `get_next_device_name', which should be
implemented by the drivers, or by calling the generic method from the
utils module `get_device_name_for_instance'.

It also takes care of assigning the correct device name to the root
device (boot_index=0) to make it agree with the field `root_device_name'
kept in the instance.

Part of blueprint: improve-block-device-handling

Change-Id: I84541f8ff6e1b5978734e5def69946d014c66fdf

Before creating the instance, the manager will check each one of the
block devices that should be attached and verify that all of them have a

valid name using the method `get_next_device_name', which should be

Change-Id: I84541f8ff6e1b5978734e5def69946d014c66fdf
"}, {'created': '2013-08-09 14:44:49.000000000', 'message': "Allow block devices without device_name

This patch removes the check in the API that prevented having block
devices without 'device_name' and makes the compute manager capable of
guessing those names.

Before creating the instance, the manager will try to guess a valid name
using the method 'default_device_names_for_instance',  which should be
implemented by the drivers, or defer to the generic function from the
utils module 'default_device_names_for_instance' which uses the already
existing 'get_device_name_for_instance' function.

It also takes care of assigning the correct device name to the root
device (boot_index=0) to make it agree with the field `root_device_name'
from the instance. If none were supplied - it will try to guess it by
calling driver 'default_root_device_name' or defer to the generic
'get_device_name_for_instance'. if driver does not provide it.

DocImpact

Part of blueprint: improve-block-device-handling

Patch was co-authored by Xavier Queralt <xqueralt@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I84541f8ff6e1b5978734e5def69946d014c66fdf

Change-Id: I84541f8ff6e1b5978734e5def69946d014c66fdf
"}, {'created': '2013-08-16 17:58:51.000000000', 'message': "Allow block devices without device_name

This patch removes the check in the API that prevented having block
devices without 'device_name' and makes the compute manager capable of
guessing those names.

Before creating the instance, the manager will try to guess a valid name
using the method 'default_device_names_for_instance',  which should be
implemented by the drivers, or defer to the generic function from the
utils module 'default_device_names_for_instance' which uses the already
existing 'get_device_name_for_instance' function.

It also takes care of assigning the correct device name to the root
device (boot_index=0) to make it agree with the field `root_device_name'
from the instance. If none were supplied - it will try to guess it by
calling driver 'default_root_device_name' or defer to the generic
'get_device_name_for_instance'. if driver does not provide it.

DocImpact

Part of blueprint: improve-block-device-handling

Co-authored-by: Xavier Queralt <xqueralt@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I84541f8ff6e1b5978734e5def69946d014c66fdf

commit_message:
Allow block devices without device_name

This patch removes the check in the API that prevented having block
devices without 'device_name' and makes the compute manager capable of
guessing those names.

Before creating the instance, the manager will try to guess a valid name
using the method 'default_device_names_for_instance',  which should be
implemented by the drivers, or defer to the generic function from the
utils module 'default_device_names_for_instance' which uses the already
existing 'get_device_name_for_instance' function.

It also takes care of assigning the correct device name to the root
device (boot_index=0) to make it agree with the field `root_device_name'
from the instance. If none were supplied - it will try to guess it by
calling driver 'default_root_device_name' or defer to the generic
'get_device_name_for_instance'. if driver does not provide it.

What is worth noting also is that, should the drivers override the
two methods mentioned above, the code should expect to be passed the
standard block device mapping format, and not the one used in other
driver methods.

DocImpact

Part of blueprint: improve-block-device-handling

Co-authored-by: Xavier Queralt <xqueralt@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I84541f8ff6e1b5978734e5def69946d014c66fdf

'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-09-02 15:29:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I'm not sure this passes the test of least surprise. To me the following is probably what would be more expected (I polled a couple of folks locally).

Imagine the following two scenarios:

1) 'cfoo' is a property which is create protected; 'foo' is an unprotected property

A user sends a POST request to create a new image which also attempts to create (and set) the 'cfoo' and 'foo' properties.

With the current implementation 200 will be returned. Since a 200 was returned users will expect that the API call succeeded and will assume that the 'cfoo' property has successfully been set (no matter what we document!). Users would have to iterate through the keys to detect otherwise, this is doable, but 'surprising'.

2) 'ufoo' is a property which is update protected, its current value is 'UFOO'; 'foo' is an unprotected property, currently set to 'FOO'

A user sends a PUT request to set the 'ufoo' property to 'XXX' and set 'foo' to 'YYY'.

With the current implementation 200 will be returned. Since a 200 was returned users will expect that the API call succeeded and will assume that the 'cfoo' property has successfully been set to 'XXX' and that 'foo' has been set to 'YYY'. Users would have to iterate through all keys/values to detect otherwise, this is doable, but, again, 'surprising', and unlikely to be done by all users, even if documented. This will lead to (from the user's point of view) unexpected behaviour.

3) 'ufoo' is a property which is update protected, its current value is 'UFOO'; 'foo' is an unprotected property, currently set to 'FOO'

A user sends a PUT request to set the 'ufoo' property to 'UFOO' and set 'foo' to 'YYY'.

With the current implementation 200 will be returned. 'foo' will have been updated, 'ufoo'
will be unchanged. This will probably be a fairly common read/modify/write pattern, which
happens to work out unsurprisingly.

I think the following is more typical:

1) return 403

2) return 403

3) return 200 (we can return 200 if the value of 'ufoo' is unchanged)"}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-09-02 15:31:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Note that this is the behaviour that currently exists for V1's 'immutable properties' (size, checksum)."}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-09-02 16:05:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Agree with Stuart! As I mentioned in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/43733/9/glance/api/property_protections.py we need give a necessary feedback approach to notice client when proxy skip property(s) changing. Http return  code is a good way.'}, {'account_id': 4463, 'date': '2013-09-03 19:18:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Makes sense  Stuart! I gave it some thought and I think I agree with you. Made changes in previous patches accordingly.

Except for maybe this case:
 ufoo = boo

and it is protected 
[ufoo]
update: spl_role

when we try to update it ufoo = boo, it should still give 403 , because it is a property which cannot be modified and even if we re trying to set the same value, we want to convey to the user that this action on this prohibited. Unless there is a strong usecase against it, I am open to hearing about it.'}, {'account_id': 4463, 'date': '2013-09-03 20:23:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-03 20:51:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Doesn't seem to work

"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-09-03 23:02:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks great with the changes that Stuart suggested.

I think for v2 at least we should go with returning 403 when you try to update a property you are not allowed to, even if you are setting it to the same value it has already. Since v2 uses PATCH, such an operation is still very explicitly trying to modify the value. Its also possible that some race conditions around that would arise.

For v1, where you need to do PUT instead to modify properties, I'm less sanguine.

Thanks Iccha! and reviewers!"}, {'account_id': 4463, 'date': '2013-09-04 03:10:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-04 03:45:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Enable protected properties in gateway

Related to bp api-v2-property-protection

Activate property protections if the config value is set.
Added the corresponding functional and unit tests.

Change-Id: If38604d812c34416b8369bf6f868a0f2509c2649

commit_message:
Fix wrong migrations

For Postgres migrations are failed.
More then we can get for mysql an error
"Specified key was too long; max key length is 1000 bytes" in b6ae66d05e3
migration in some versions of dialect.

Fixes-Bug: #1219776

Change-Id: Id9b0e1eb0e685053291367f7eb62fef68b6b2f84

Thanks for the update.

Let me confirm the expected command line example if I want to pass multiple dhcp options before reviewing the latest patch set.

According to the test case, the following looks expected. Is it right?

   quantum port-create --extra-dhcp-opt opt_name=bootfile-name,opt_value=pxelinux.0,opt_name=tftp-server,opt_value=123.123.123.123,opt_name=server-ip-address,opt_value=123.123.123.45 net1

Other options of quantum command which takes a list value look like:

   quantum port-create --fixed-ip ip_address=10.10.10.10 --fixed-ip 20.20.20.20 net1

It is better to use the same format, I think the following is better.
What do you think?

   quantum port-create \
      --extra-dhcp-opt opt_name=bootfile-name,opt_value=pxelinux.0 \
      --extra-dhcp-opt opt_name=tftp-server,opt_value=123.123.123.123 \
      --extra-dhcp-opt opt_name=server-ip-address,opt_value=123.123.123.45 \
      net1

Last time I reviewed, the last example was in mind and I commented based on it.
When I read your comment on patch set 3 and relooked the unit test, I noticed this.

If we get in the same page, I believe this patch will land soon.

Thanks,'}, {'account_id': 5572, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 5572, 'date': '2013-07-06 16:06:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5572, 'date': '2013-07-16 14:33:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
bp:pxeboot-ports, provide pxboot on ports

Teach neutron how to manage PXE boot.

Allow pxe boot parameters to be specified when creating a network port.

Implements bp:pxeboot-ports

Change-Id: Id6e41a0896150a62384fcd3fe9b42f1d7555109b

'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-07-22 05:58:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Are you using the update.py module in requirements sync versions? Babel can't end up in test-requirements.txt if you used update.py since it's in requirements.txt in the requirements project."}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2013-07-22 07:07:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/35472/ update.py does handle it as well. 

Anyway, you -1'ed it, so how is Babel used during runtime in Nova? I was not able to find a use of it. Most other OpenStack modules only have it in test-requires as well."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-07-22 07:11:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Well my point is that the requirements file should be updated by only using the update.py module. If Babel is only used in tests the Babel should move to test-requirements.txt in openstack/requirements. I'll also check if other projects use it on runtime."}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2013-07-22 07:52:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I generally agree, but update.py does not move requirements between the two files.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-07-22 08:09:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yes update.py only syncs the requirements.txt and test-requirements.txt in requirements with the ones in the target project base dir. Therefore if we want to put Babel in test-requirement.txt, a patch that moves Babel from requirements.txt to test-requirements.txt should first land in requirements and then use update.py to sync with nova.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-07-23 04:54:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Can you update the commit message with details of why its safe to remove the two dependencies."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-30 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-21 14:09:24.000000000', 'message': 'Clean up dependencies

Only direct dependencies need to be listed in requirements.txt.
Move Babel to test-requires, as it is not used at runtime.

Change-Id: I45bdd1d0dabfcc7c80314c28072950cfc5a59615
'}, {'created': '2013-08-04 14:33:13.000000000', 'message': 'Remove indirect dependencies from requirements.txt

Only direct dependencies need to be listed in requirements.txt.
pyparsing and python-keystoneclient were previously added to
workaround installation ordering issues, which is no longer
necessary.

Move Babel to test-requires, as it is not used at runtime,
only for the extracting the message catalog run.

Change-Id: I45bdd1d0dabfcc7c80314c28072950cfc5a59615
'}, {'created': '2013-08-14 10:00:36.000000000', 'message': 'Remove indirect dependencies from requirements.txt

Only direct dependencies need to be listed in requirements.txt.
pyparsing and python-keystoneclient were previously added to
workaround installation ordering issues, which is no longer
necessary.

Change-Id: I45bdd1d0dabfcc7c80314c28072950cfc5a59615
'}, {'created': '2013-08-22 20:06:04.000000000', 'message': 'Remove indirect dependency from requirements.txt

Only direct dependencies need to be listed in requirements.txt.

commit_message:
Remove indirect dependency from requirements.txt

Only direct dependencies need to be listed in requirements.txt.
pyparsing was previously added to workaround installation ordering
issues, which is no longer necessary.

Change-Id: I45bdd1d0dabfcc7c80314c28072950cfc5a59615

commit_message:
Allow 'any' option for protocol in the firewall rule

Closes-Bug: #1217212

The current allowed values for
protocol are tcp, udp and icmp. Adding
'any' as allowed option. Since the
API expects 'None' value for 'any',
the 'create' and 'update' changes the
args to 'None' when 'any' is set.

Change-Id: I33cdf62244f2217379c40a8cd4c776382935ef17

Deprecate conductor migration_get()

It's no longer used.  Deprecate it.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

commit_message:
Fix bug#1220351 Create Cloud Administrator Guide

Create a new guide from the remains of Compute, Object Storage, Block Storage, and Networking Administration Guides left over from removal of install and config specific info.

Remove gerunds from the headings based on the OS Docs Style, correct links refs, insert chapter and section tags.

Update pom file to reflect the appropriate disqus registration

Update section names for loose xi:include files

Move figures to Common folder and update xrefs

Author: Nermina Miller

Change-Id: I21cf53e26c25d75ad1b75ec7449e8e1a7e4b9bb2

'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2013-09-04 00:22:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

I think these tests failed because neutron.agent.linux.ovs_lib.py:get_vif_port_by_id() isn't being properly mocked out when running these tests:

neutron.tests.unit.nec.test_nec_plugin.TestNecPortsV2.test_update_port_add_additional_ip

neutron.tests.unit.openvswitch.test_openvswitch_plugin.TestOpenvswitchPortsV2.test_update_port

neutron.tests.unit.openvswitch.test_openvswitch_plugin.TestOpenvswitchPortsV2.test_update_port_update_ips

neutron.tests.unit.openvswitch.test_ovs_lib.OVS_Lib_Test.test_get_vif_port_set_list_interface_error

neutron.tests.unit.openvswitch.test_ovs_lib.OVS_Lib_Test.test_get_vif_port_set_list_ports_error

neutron.tests.unit.ryu.test_ryu_plugin.TestRyuPortsV2.test_update_port

neutron.tests.unit.ryu.test_ryu_plugin.TestRyuPortsV2.test_update_port_delete_ip

neutron.tests.unit.ryu.test_ryu_plugin.TestRyuPortsV2.test_update_port_not_admin

neutron.tests.unit.ryu.test_ryu_plugin.TestRyuPortsV2.test_update_port_update_ip

neutron.tests.unit.ryu.test_ryu_plugin.TestRyuPortsV2.test_update_port_update_ips

You can see where these sudo's are logged and fail in http://logs.openstack.org/58/43558/12/gate/gate-neutron-python27/0c9055f/subunit_log.txt.gz.

This is probably an intertest conflict where one test must run before the others to properly mock things out or one test running first removes the mocks that the others depend on."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-09-04 02:15:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

I investigated some failing tests. All failing tests come from common db plugin tests. These tests check the server side features but the agent side code (ovs_lib vif method) is called as Clark reported. It seems that RPC notifier is not properly mocked. I checked nec plugin and noticed it does not mock RPC notifier in TestNecPortsV2. nec plugin should add the following to NecPluginV2TestCase.setUp() before calling super().setUp():

  mock.patch(' (neutron.plugins.nec.nec_plugin.NECPluginV2AgentNotifierApi').start().

I think tests in OVS plugin and Ryu plugin lack the similar notifier mocking. 
(Now I am out of office and it is based on a static review. I hope someone check the OVS and ryu test code.)"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-09-04 10:02:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

We have unfortunately plenty of race conditions in our unit tests.
I don't think this patch makes them worse, so I think we should try and reverify it. The gate is busy now, I will queue the job later."}, {'account_id': 4726, 'date': '2013-09-05 08:30:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

I checked Ryu plugin test code. There is a similar problem as Akihiro said.
I think that lack of mocking of the notifier is a problem, but, I'm not sure why the agent code was performed via rpc on a unit test."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-09-05 10:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

reverify no bug'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-05 10:24:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: No score

Starting gate jobs.

commit_message:
Implement MidoNet Neutron plugin for Havana

Implement L2, L3, security groups, metadata server support for
MidoNet Neutron plugin for Havana.

blueprint midonet-plugin-havana

Change-Id: I0dd1a2ca17d760443c4c7a464a66b6d0a2cf194a

subject: XenAPI: Allow 10GB overhead on VHD file check size

"}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-08-10 06:57:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't understand this change really; but it seems as though the 1.4 is a fudge factor.  Why 40% and not 50% or 30%?  If it is a fudge factor, perhaps we're checking the wrong thing here.

Is the intention to check the physical utilisation?  In which case that is unrelated to root_gb size, which is the virtual utilisation?  Why are we comparing physical to virtual in this case?"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-12 22:22:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with Bob"}, {'account_id': 7802, 'date': '2013-08-15 23:54:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Joe and Bob,

This check is just for physical utilization of the VHD files. I believe that virtual utilization is generally handled by min_disk on builds.

Would it be more appropriate to remove the check altogether? VHD files have overhead and can easily grow to be greater than root_gb.

Thanks,
Teran'}, {'account_id': 7802, 'date': '2013-08-16 00:10:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I can see this going one of three ways. The check is removed, a static fudge factor is added, or I write a custom fudge factor set by nova.conf.

Of course, another database entry could also be made, but I think that complexifies things even more than necessary.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-08-16 02:53:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

whatever the solution static fudge factors is not it.'}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-08-16 06:21:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not clear on what this check is testing.

It seems to be adding all of the physical sizes for the chain of VHDs - which of course could end up as many times the root_gb size in the general case (with many snapshots if they have all had a large amount of data written).

The check of sum-of-data-written/overwritten against the total size of the disk doesn't make sense to me - and it's not clear what the purpose is.  It is a very long standing check (added in pre-gerrit commit b60fa0d09d02066863736a3e98f07094c4db05a6) and doesn't make much sense to me without the context.

However, I'd suggest involving a few others who may know more about the history."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-08-19 14:15:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This check is added to protect against user snapshots using up more space that their flavor allows. Min_disk is just saying what flavor *should* be OK, mostly from a virtual disk size, and partition size perspective.

Obviously the VDI chain means its normal that it could occur. There is a limit on the size of the VDI chains.

Not sure of the best approach at this point. It seems right to have an upper limit on this, this is certainly one way. I need to give it more thought.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-08-19 14:15:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

-1 for the unit tests issue."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-08-20 14:26:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-20 15:12:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Agree that static fudge-factor is probably not a good solution here.

We probably want to have some way of capping snapshot size though.

We could use a configurable overhead expressed in relation to root_gb, or we could have a completely separate field in `instance_types` that holds `max_snapshot_size_gb`.

Other options here?"}, {'account_id': 7802, 'date': '2013-08-20 19:51:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7802, 'date': '2013-08-20 19:53:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks for all of the feedback. This is now just a simple and static 10GB overhead. I know that there are no unit tests at present, although I feel it would be helpful to push this through and then follow up with unit tests and possibly additional changes at a later date.'}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-08-20 20:00:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I still don't understand the reason for this check and the need for this change - I think a better explanation in the commit message is needed.

If the problem is that we're starting images which have an existing VHD chain and we're allowing that to be 10GB more than the root_gb size then I can understand it, but we need to have a mirrored check on VHD upload to make sure that we won't fall foul of this check.

That is, if we should keep this check at all?"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-08-20 20:08:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Where does 10GB come from?

On a large instance w/ heavy I/O, seems like 10GB would be too little, and on a small instance with low I/O 10GB would seem too much.

Since there doesn't appear to be a way of getting an exact number here, really feels like this needs to be tunable."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-20 22:31:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

Logic is wrong - seems to be 10GB _lower_ than allowed_size.

But I'd still recommend against merging this until there is more explanation about why we want to keep this check but add a fudge factor."}, {'account_id': 7802, 'date': '2013-08-22 17:12:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 7802, 'date': '2013-08-22 17:13:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hi Bob,

I agree. I'm just trying to find a working test that can be used as a workaround if need be. I think the ideal scenario may be removal of the test, myself. We probably shouldn't be sending VHD chains too much larger than desired to the host in the first place, anyways.

Thanks,
Teran"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-22 18:32:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

Hi Brian,

Thanks for your feedback. Does the new comment around the fudge factor constant look good to you?

10GB is arbitrary from experience. In production, this bug usually comes up with a couple GB at most of overhead over root_gb. 10GB is to cover most edge cases you will encounter, while not being so far out there to likely cause issues if something unexpected happens. Ultimately, 10GB seems like a reasonable compromise until we come up with a better long term fix if one is needed.

Thanks,

'}, {'created': '2013-09-02 18:26:57.000000000', 'message': "XenAPI: Allow 10GB overhead on VHD file check size

_check_vdi_size in vm_utils.py does not account for VHD overhead. Builds
will fail if on disk VHD file usage is even slightly greater than the
root_gb partition allocation size to the VM.

With VHDs, VM root disks usually come from two-file chains (one, if a
snapshot has never been taken or it was not a fast copy build). There is
a mild file format overhead involved and additionally, once a block has
been written to, the space is never freed or compressed from the VHD
file. The two VHD files in the chain may have overlapping blocks adding
to the total amount of overhead over the actual utilization. This can
result in a VM's partition internally not even being full, with the
external VHD File chain being even just a few MB larger than the allowed
size. Building from an image of such a VM will fail due to this check
expecting external/on-disk usage to never be greater than the internal
partion size granted.

This patch adds a 10GB tolerance which should fix almost all cases of
build failures due to this bug.

Fixes: bug #1216042

Change-Id: I69f47351fe83e54775e0147a27450c21196f9bfd

commit_message:
XenAPI: Allow 10GB overhead on VHD file check size

_check_vdi_size in vm_utils.py does not account for VHD overhead. Builds
will fail if on disk VHD file usage is even slightly greater than the
root_gb partition allocation size to the VM.

With VHDs, VM root disks usually come from two-file chains (one, if a
snapshot has never been taken or it was not a fast copy build). There is
a mild file format overhead involved and additionally, once a block has
been written to, the space is never freed or compressed from the VHD
file. The two VHD files in the chain may have overlapping blocks adding
to the total amount of overhead over the actual utilization. This can
result in a VM's partition internally not even being full, with the
external VHD File chain being even just a few MB larger than the allowed
size. Building from an image of such a VM will fail due to this check
expecting external/on-disk usage to never be greater than the internal
partion size granted.

This patch adds a 10GB tolerance which should fix almost all cases of
build failures due to this bug.

Fixes: bug #1216042

Change-Id: I69f47351fe83e54775e0147a27450c21196f9bfd

commit_message:
Fix the multi-instance quota message

Make sure that when spawning multiple instance, the quota exceeded
error still makes sense. Instead of reporting min_count (1) as the
requested number, report "between min_count and max_count".

Fixes bug 1211347

Change-Id: I5a562253788f93b932ccd99bd1dc6630444bd430

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-30 19:53:43.000000000', 'message': 'fix: Claim can return 404

This patch changes the way creating a claim behaves when the
queue does not exist. Instead of returning 404, it returns
204, meaning the claim was not able to find any messages to
claim.

This was done for two reasons:

1. For eventually-consistent backends, a brand new queue may
not appear to exist, so this new semantic allows the driver
to just try to grab some messages without checking first
whether the queue "exists".
2. For backends like MongoDB that require an extra check to
determine whether a queue exists, this removes an extra
round trip to the DB in order to perform the operation.

Note that the SQLite driver was updated in order to be
consistent with the new behavior.

Change-Id: Icde4ce493a76ef145e99300b67d8344d5092e38d
Closes-Bug: #1218990
'}, {'created': '2013-08-30 20:33:40.000000000', 'message': 'fix: Claim can return 404

commit_message:
fix: Claim can return 404

This patch changes the way creating a claim behaves when the
queue does not exist. Instead of returning 404, it returns
204, meaning the claim was not able to find any messages to
claim.

This was done for two reasons:

1. For eventually-consistent backends, a brand new queue may
not appear to exist, so this new semantic allows the driver
to just try to grab some messages without checking first
whether the queue "exists".
2. For backends like MongoDB that require an extra check to
determine whether a queue exists, this removes an extra
round trip to the DB in order to perform the operation.

Note that the SQLite driver was updated in order to be
consistent with the new behavior.

Change-Id: Icde4ce493a76ef145e99300b67d8344d5092e38d
Partial-Bug: #1218990

Iptables metering driver

this is a part of the blueprint bandwidth-router-measurement

Change-Id: I37e4dc5abeaca4e13b32155bb7e2f07883ef9b2d

commit_message:
Add method to get iptables traffic counters

Add methods to iptables_manager to get traffic counters.
this is a part of the blueprint bandwidth-router-measurement

commit_message:
Allow None for binding:profile attribute

We need to pass None in binding:profile to allow an administrator
to clear binding:profile attribute.

Closes-Bug: #1220011

Adds dedicated unit tests to the plugins which uses binding:profile
attribute (Mellanox and NEC plugins at now).

This commit also adds common unit tests for binding:profile to
the common PortBindingTestCase class.
- create_port with binding:profile whose value is None or {}
- update_port with binding:profile whose value is None or {}
- Reject binding:profile from non-admin user

Note that _make_port() in BigSwitch plugin test is updated
to allow passing arg_list() from the base test class.

Fix a bug in NEC plugin that 500 is returned when putting
binding:profile None to a port whose binding:profile is
already None (Closes-Bug: #1220720)

Change-Id: I146afe961cd445a023adc7233588d8034fdb8437

commit_message:
Prefetcher should perform data integrity check

When prefetching into cache we should verify the image data checksum.

Fixes bug 882585.

Change-Id: I01211894d0d76d69cbf92fe726fbed56326d950d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-29 11:07:11.000000000', 'message': 'xenapi: enable block device access for stack user

Although nova is setting the permissions on block devices, sometimes it
fails, and that results in an instance failing to launch. It is only an
issue for 3-part images, and images accessed through block devices. This
patch adds an udev rule, so that devices will be accessible.

fixes bug 1218251

Change-Id: I837ea515457fbfc50e9ce138ea9de9db12baa8be
'}]
commit_message:
xenapi: enable block device access for stack user

Although nova is setting the permissions on block devices, sometimes it
fails, and that results in an instance failing to launch. It is only an
issue for 3-part images, and images accessed through block devices. This
patch adds an udev rule, so that devices will be accessible.

fixes bug 1218251

Change-Id: I837ea515457fbfc50e9ce138ea9de9db12baa8be

commit_message:
This adds a README to brick

We need to let folks know where brick is
currently being maintained for the Havana
release and where to file defects.
Once this simple patch lands, we'll pull this into
the Nova patch.

(fix hacking violation in commit message for the 2nd
time on this patch. To prevent it from blocking the
merge queue on feature freeze day.)

PLEASE DON'T +A PATCHES UNTIL THEY PASS JENKINS CHECK

Change-Id: I5c4569c1c09751d53817ee9577581e530a3a8352

commit_message:
Fix localisation string usage

The format string for localisation needs to be a fixed
literal, otherwise translation tools do not work.

Change-Id: I8e0e38df15ec61a0ccbfa41c3ccaed3a01d1d4d5

commit_message:
Ensure unit tests do not let looping calls roam freely

Bug 1220871

This patch does minimal changes in neutron.plugins.nicira.common.sync
providing unit tests with a reference to the looping call object, so
that they can control its lifecycle.
Also, it perform a bit of refactoring in test_l3_agent.py in the way
mocks are created and started.

Change-Id: I73a1eb8ecdb7c6d46ff12afba549dd27095b7202

[{'created': '2013-09-04 11:59:40.000000000', 'message': 'Do not run preemptive actions twice

When table action is preemptive , it needs to run
only once, before the table data is loaded.

Fixes bug 1182661
Change-Id: Ibb7ed5f97f64cfc9e56b317ed9d4b5e8cbf8cc8c

commit_message:
Do not run preemptive actions twice

When table action is preemptive , it needs to run
only once, before the table data is loaded.

Fixes bug 1182661
Change-Id: Ibb7ed5f97f64cfc9e56b317ed9d4b5e8cbf8cc8c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-05 09:34:10.000000000', 'message': "Fixe misusing assertTrue in unit test

Misusing assertTrue lead to invalid unit test , can't detect
the real issue. I didn't fix these misusing that in another review
see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/45151/

Change-Id: I032f99e4313206bb2415635f99b6931f8f97bb13

commit_message:
Fixe misusing assertTrue in unit test

Misusing assertTrue lead to invalid unit test , can't detect
the real issue.

Change-Id: I032f99e4313206bb2415635f99b6931f8f97bb13

commit_message:
VMDK copy_image_to_volume and copy_volume_to_image

Implemented copy_image_to_volume that creates a new volume backing (vm) and
copies over the vmdk file from the glance image. Only glance images of disk
format 'vmdk' can be used to create a volume using this driver.

Also implemented copy_volume_to_image that creates a new glance image using
the volume's vmdk file. The steps involved are to take a snapshot of volume
vmdk, take a copy of this read only file and upload to glance.

Cleaned up docstrings as pointed out in earlier reviews.

Added timeout to avoid blocking wait on read/write threads and also fixed a
bug to upload image from copy of vmdk instead of from original vmdk during
upload to glance.

Implements: blueprint vmware-vmdk-cinder-driver
Change-Id: I00d22861f4e01ae0862dbf4b60af314c475b7d38

commit_message:
Restrict Volume type deletion with volumes assoc

Updated the delete_volume method to wait till the
volume is deleted before type is delted.

Closes-Bug: #1215329

tag:doc-impact

Change-Id: I7a5d4b473588757d21b461337df493e8046e1d09

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-29 23:59:51.000000000', 'message': "Port to oslo.messaging.Notifier API

Add a temporary nova.notifier.Notifier helper class which translates
oslo.messaging.Notifier compatible calls into openstack.common.notifier
compatible calls.

This allows us to port the notifier code over to the oslo.messaging API
before actually switching over oslo.messaging fully.

This patch contains no functional changes at all, except that all
notifications go through this temporary helper class.

Some notes on the new API:

  * The notifier API is changed so that what was previously global state
    is now encapsulated in a Notifier object. This object also includes
    the publisher_id and has error()/info()/etc. methods rather than
    just notify().

  * The notify_decorator() helper wasn't carried across to the new API
    because its semantics are a bit weird. Something along these lines
    could be added in future, though.

  * We use a fake Notifier implementation for tests because there's no
    API in oslo.messaging to actually get the notifications queued
    up in the fake notification driver, which is a bit dumb. However,
    this feels like the right thing to do anyway. We're not wanting
    to test oslo.messaging.Notifier itself, but rather we want to test
    who we call it.

blueprint: oslo-messaging
Change-Id: I262163c7e05e6a6fb79265e904ce761fc3ac5806

Add a temporary nova.notifier.Notifier helper class which translates
oslo.messaging.Notifier compatible calls into openstack.common.notifier
compatible calls.

This allows us to port the notifier code over to the oslo.messaging API
before actually switching over oslo.messaging fully.

This patch contains no functional changes at all, except that all
notifications go through this temporary helper class.

Some notes on the new API:

  * The notifier API is changed so that what was previously global state
    is now encapsulated in a Notifier object. This object also includes
    the publisher_id and has error()/info()/etc. methods rather than
    just notify().

  * The notify_decorator() helper wasn't carried across to the new API
    because its semantics are a bit weird. Something along these lines
    could be added in future, though.

  * We use a fake Notifier implementation for tests because there's no
    API in oslo.messaging to actually get the notifications queued
    up in the fake notification driver, which is a bit dumb. However,
    this feels like the right thing to do anyway. We're not wanting
    to test oslo.messaging.Notifier itself, but rather we want to test
    who we call it.

blueprint: oslo-messaging
Change-Id: I262163c7e05e6a6fb79265e904ce761fc3ac5806

commit_message:
Port to oslo.messaging.Notifier API

Add a temporary nova.notifier.Notifier helper class which translates
oslo.messaging.Notifier compatible calls into openstack.common.notifier
compatible calls.

This allows us to port the notifier code over to the oslo.messaging API
before actually switching over oslo.messaging fully.

This patch contains no functional changes at all, except that all
notifications go through this temporary helper class.

Some notes on the new API:

  * The notifier API is changed so that what was previously global state
    is now encapsulated in a Notifier object. This object also includes
    the publisher_id and has error()/info()/etc. methods rather than
    just notify().

  * The notify_decorator() helper wasn't carried across to the new API
    because its semantics are a bit weird. Something along these lines
    could be added in future, though.

  * We use a fake Notifier implementation for tests because there's no
    API in oslo.messaging to actually get the notifications queued
    up in the fake notification driver, which is a bit dumb. However,
    this feels like the right thing to do anyway. We're not wanting
    to test oslo.messaging.Notifier itself, but rather we want to test
    how we call it.

blueprint: oslo-messaging
Change-Id: I262163c7e05e6a6fb79265e904ce761fc3ac5806

commit_message:
Fix ArchiveTestCase on PostgreSQL

test_archive_deleted_rows_no_id_column() filters DnsDomain instances by
value of 'deleted' column (which is of type Boolean). Integer value 1
is passed instead of boolean value True. This works great on MySQL and
SQLite, but fails on PostgreSQL which is more strict when checking data
types of passed values.

Blueprint: db-api-tests-on-all-backends

Change-Id: I06c8ba323cff02804d0aef3bf56892c111f67226

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-08-19 21:33:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This all looks great. Just a couple of questions before i sign off on it.

1) I'm assuming that pci-passthrough means that live migration will not work. Is that correct?

2) have you tested booting an instance with pci passthrough and using reboot, stop/start, suspend/resume, etc.?"}, {'account_id': 4573, 'date': '2013-08-19 21:49:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

Vish, thanks for the review.

Yes, with pci passthrough, by default live migration will not work. However, with some setup, it should works well for NIC devices as in http://ols.fedoraproject.org/OLS/Reprints-2008/zhai-reprint.pdf .

We focused on create and delete VM and it works well, you raised a really good point of the suspend/resume etc and we will do more testing on these scenerio and back to you.'}, {'account_id': 7543, 'date': '2013-08-21 03:33:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-21 05:51:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Works for me

Hi,Daniel Berrange

i re-investigating the problem, i found:

1.) we now re-assign the pci device only after the instance be deleted
and
2. _destroy will wait the destroy to compete, then all pci device detach will be
complete.

so i don't think we got synchronization problem here, what do you think?"}, {'account_id': 4573, 'date': '2013-08-27 06:43:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
PCI passthrough Libvirt vm config

PCI passthrough device's xml config formatter. adding pci
passthrough device to VM, and detach it from a VM. adapter the
hypervisor PCI passthrough devices management interface given a
unify interface to other PCI passthrough components.

bp:pci-passthrough-libvirt

Co-authored-by: Boris Pavlovic <boris@pavlovic.me>
Change-Id: If55648e5cc2ed5b7ea44aad08205689d99338856
Signed-off-by: Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-02 08:17:59.000000000', 'message': "fix buggy lazy loading 'pci_devices'

libvirt:snapshot -> instance.save() expect 'pci_devices', but instance
save will not join loading the pci_devices, then  _from_db_object try
to access db_inst['pci_devices'] will tigger a buggy lazy loading.

Change-Id: Ib324fdf02f3d462970cdf7c7065ddc3d87f72fba
Signed-off-by: Yongli He
"}, {'created': '2013-09-02 09:22:06.000000000', 'message': "fix buggy lazy loading 'pci_devices'

libvirt:snapshot -> instance.save() expect 'pci_devices', but instance
save will not join loading the pci_devices, then  _from_db_object try
to access db_inst['pci_devices'] will tigger a buggy lazy loading.

Change-Id: Ib324fdf02f3d462970cdf7c7065ddc3d87f72fba
Signed-off-by: Yongli He
"}, {'created': '2013-09-03 16:36:24.000000000', 'message': "fix buggy lazy loading 'pci_devices' in instance.save

If 'pci_devices' is set in an instance object, instance.save() expects
'pci_devices' attribute when calling _from_db_object(), but instance
save will not join loading the pci_devices. When _from_db_object()
accesses db_inst['pci_devices'], it will tigger a buggy lazy loading.

Change-Id: Ib324fdf02f3d462970cdf7c7065ddc3d87f72fba
Signed-off-by: Yongli He
"}, {'created': '2013-09-03 22:45:19.000000000', 'message': 'Add columns_to_join to instance_update_and_get_original

expecected columns to be returned.

commit_message:
Add columns_to_join to instance_update_and_get_original

Add a parameter to instance_update_and_get_original() to specify the
expecected columns to be returned.

Change-Id: Ib324fdf02f3d462970cdf7c7065ddc3d87f72fba
Signed-off-by: Yongli He

parallelize StackResource delete

This is fourth and last  patch in the series to implement
parallel delete. In this patch, parallelizing StackResource
deletion.

Blueprint parallel-delete

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-04 18:30:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes brick Nova pep8 violation for lvm.py

Running pep8 tests in Nova gives a violation
in lvm.py for not importing a module.  This
is a simple fix to import the module itself
instead of only importing a function in the
module.

Fixes bug #1220849

Change-Id: Idc603dcfab18601dd4246c623d34be5933434f84
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes brick Nova pep8 violation for lvm.py

Running pep8 tests in Nova gives a violation
in lvm.py for not importing a module.  This
is a simple fix to import the module itself
instead of only importing a function in the
module.

Fixes bug #1220849

Change-Id: Idc603dcfab18601dd4246c623d34be5933434f84

Hi Kaiwei,

here's an initial barrage of questions and comments.
The only bit I would like to understand better is how callbacks are populated into the 'callbacks' attribute of the edge appliance driver.

Also - I think we still need some unit tests for this patch, is that right?

The rest is pretty much nits and questions."}, {'account_id': 6461, 'date': '2013-08-29 03:53:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: (25 inline comments)

The callbacks are a set of predefined methods that will be triggered during asynchronous API pricessing. For example, when deploying an Edge asynchronously, our API will trigger two callbacks, edge_deploy_started() and edge_deploy_result(). Other APIs will have their only callbacks. We just group all these callback methods within a class, and pass an instance of such class the VcnsDriver. Whenever we need to trigger a callback, we just invoke instance.callback_function.

I think the unit test cases covers most APIs, except delete_edge and update_interface. I'll add them. The other test case I think worth adding is to test if the TaskManager process tasks for different resources concurrently."}, {'account_id': 6461, 'date': '2013-08-29 08:17:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-29 08:43:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Works for me

[{'created': '2013-08-20 21:35:22.000000000', 'message': 'VCNS driver implementation

Implement API/driver interface for configuring vShield Edge Appliance.

Currently implemented functions:
    - Deploy an Edge
    - Destroy an Edge
    - Configuring interfaces
    - Configuring SNAT/DNAT rules
    - Configuring default gateway and static routes
    - Query Edge status
    - Task-based asynchronous model

Implements: blueprint vcns-driver

commit_message:
VCNS driver implementation

Implement API/driver interface for configuring vShield Edge Appliance.

Currently implemented functions:
    - Deploy an Edge
    - Destroy an Edge
    - Configuring interfaces
    - Configuring SNAT/DNAT rules
    - Configuring default gateway and static routes
    - Query Edge status
    - Task-based asynchronous model
    - Allow old routes/nat config to be skipped if new updates are coming

Implements: blueprint vcns-driver
Change-Id: I881bde907f4c90de4c919d008b76b8c2a2d0e1fd

ceilometer-alarm-singleton's name is ceilometer-alarm-eval in devstack.
ceilometer-alarm-notifier's name is ceilometer-alarm-notify in devstack.

Change-Id: I7b39818ecce595351593040f43ee7486e66cc042

commit_message:
doc: Fix service name for devstack

ceilometer-alarm-singleton's name is ceilometer-alarm-eval in devstack.
ceilometer-alarm-notifier's name is ceilometer-alarm-notify in devstack.

Change-Id: I7b39818ecce595351593040f43ee7486e66cc042

The pattern for the 'sudo nova-rootwrap' command was duplicated
throughout the code.  Put it in one place in nova.utils.

commit_message:
Add nova.utils.get_root_helper()

The pattern for the 'sudo nova-rootwrap' command was duplicated
throughout the code.  Put it in one place in nova.utils.

Change-Id: I0d4edfa5a53c3b9a9fa43864f5daaa17a0d024a1

[{'created': '2013-08-28 13:06:57.000000000', 'message': "Implement the server side of ZmqDriver

This implements the server side of the driver without modifying the
existing code by allowing the driver to spawn off multiple greenthreads
as before, but queueing any dispatched messages so that the executor

Change-Id: Ie299c2695d81d0473cea81d40114326b89de0011

commit_message:
Implement the server side of ZmqDriver

This implements the server side of the driver without modifying the
existing code by allowing the driver to spawn off multiple greenthreads
as before, but queueing any dispatched messages so that the executor
can still do listener.poll() to dispatch messages itself.

This is a hack, but it's a starting point.

Change-Id: Ie299c2695d81d0473cea81d40114326b89de0011

commit_message:
Check the parameter enabled before db_sync

Setting enabled to false ensures that the api service is not running
and the db schema is not create/migrated.

Change-Id: Idf4bfea0d21bfb4a0ca2c3c426961340a7d84be5

[{'created': '2013-08-28 13:06:57.000000000', 'message': "Import zmq driver code with minimal modifications

Modifications are:

  - use stdlib logging; no huge need for oslo logging here

  - stub out the _() function; we don't have any l10n infrastructure in
    the project and may never have

  - change imports to oslo.messaging.openstack.common and
    oslo.messaging._drivers as appropriate

Change-Id: I87b85b79a33dec65e51ed95fff90cc56042240c5
"}]
commit_message:
Import zmq driver code with minimal modifications

Modifications are:

  - use stdlib logging; no huge need for oslo logging here

  - stub out the _() function; we don't have any l10n infrastructure in
    the project and may never have

  - change imports to oslo.messaging.openstack.common and
    oslo.messaging._drivers as appropriate

Change-Id: I87b85b79a33dec65e51ed95fff90cc56042240c5

Does this requires an updated version of pymongo? Because my pymongo 2.5.2 fails. (see my comment)"}, {'account_id': 7399, 'date': '2013-09-03 09:12:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I also have pymongo v2.5.2 and it worked for me.  I'm also using the 10gen version of MongoDB, which is v2.4.5"}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2013-09-03 09:17:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@Terri, sorry, mine is 2.5.1.'}, {'account_id': 7763, 'date': '2013-09-03 13:19:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Disabling mongo connection pooling just to run the tests correctly is a very bad idea. This will have terrible performance impact on production deployments.

The problem itself is not in the mongo connection pool but in the way we are using MongoClient in tests.

We should change tests in a way that it would release all MongoClient references after test is finished. With such approach object will be destroyed and connection will be closed. Basically we are supposed to have only 1 MongoClient instance alive for the whole application. Another approach would be to share MongoClient instance between tests. I'll try to work on it when I'll have some time available."}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2013-09-04 21:10:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-04 21:53:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

commit_message:
Disable the pymongo pooling feature for tests

Because pymongo doesn't close connection on .close() when we use its
pool, we disable the MongoClient pooling feature for running tests.

This allow to use a normal number of connection in mongod for test.

Fixes bug #1218488

Change-Id: Ie4c74620937816ed0592f5ac72de99dee3173ad8

commit_message:
Fixed nova notifier unit test

This fixed the bug #1221033 caused by the latest nova chagnes.

Temproarily enlarge the max allowed connection to mongoDB as a
workaround for bug #1218488. That bug should be addressed by
https://review.openstack.org/44465

Change-Id: I49d82bcc2c1ac6481b0f5d321db2f70549a95d55

commit_message:
ML2 Mechanism Driver for Cisco Nexus

Port of the quantum/plugin/cisco/nexus plugin to run under the Modular
Layer 2 (ML2) infrastructure as defined in
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/quantum/+spec/ml2-mechanism-drivers

Implements blueprint ml2-md-cisco-nexus

Change-Id: Ifdd03bec554a08266de859387f1901858a3be4a1

'}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-08-29 11:29:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Ready For Review

If this approach is deemed acceptable, perhaps the current outstanding issue (LOG output inside tests) can be fixed after feature freeze.'}, {'account_id': 6230, 'date': '2013-08-29 17:03:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This is a great usability improvement.

I am not sure where the cookie is cleared other than aging out. I was thinking of the case where someone gets logged out and then logs in again but with the wrong password. I think they would still see the logged out message from the cookie.

Perhaps we could clear the cookie after it has been displayed to the user once."}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-09-03 10:20:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Rob,

Thank you for the review. The cookie is cleared only via aging out at the moment, as you mention. It's short lived (one minute) to avoid displaying the wrong message for too long. We could perhaps make it even shorter (since it's only needed during the time it takes to redirect to the login page).

We're restricted in how we can clear the cookie (or display a message) because the login and logout mechanisms are handled by an external plug-in, usually django_openstack_auth but not necessarily. The only thing that is really under Horizon's control when it comes to logging in and displaying message is the template, and unfortunately I'm not aware of a way to clear a cookie from there. If you can think of a better way or an alternative approach, let me know. I hit a number of walls with this trying to gracefully handle the limitations.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 6230, 'date': '2013-09-03 16:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Understood that openstack-auth and horizon interplay does make this issue tricky to handle. This seems like a valuable change with the risk of showing stale error message occasionally.'}, {'account_id': 5280, 'date': '2013-09-03 16:56:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Just to play devil's advocate: if there are changes in django-openstack-auth that would facilitate a cleaner implementation of this functionality, that is probably very much worth looking into.

Fixing the third-party library and updating requirements.txt should always be an option."}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-09-03 17:32:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

In my mind the django_openstack_auth is more "pluggable" than the other requirements and I imagine it to be replaceable by someone who would decide to use a different authentication backend. It's also meant to be reusable and not only bound to Horizon so perhaps a change that is too specific to Horizon and its UI (as opposed to authentication specific) would not fit in well.

If that's a mistaken assumption though, it would indeed be worthwhile updating it to clear the cookie on a login attempt, at the very least. I'll look into it. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 5623, 'date': '2013-09-03 19:46:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Just a translation mechanics issue, otherwise looks great.  Thanks for adding this.  I was sorely needed."}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-09-03 22:15:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
Display a message on the login page

In some cases, particularly when having to log the user out after
performing some action (e.g. password change), we want to display a
friendly message on the login screen to explain to the user why they
have been redirected to the login page.

This adds a function to do so, and uses it in a couple of places:
 - When updating one's own password using the Settings panel
 - Session time out
 - HTTP 401

Change-Id: Ie53c5552159304e1f1304ac6211b3accfd9aa623
Implements: blueprint messages-on-login-page

commit_message:
Change finish_revert_resize paths to use objects

Converts calls to compute's finish_revert_resize to pass new-world instance
and migration objects.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: Iee4a47b3dbe96f66c061b51ae9512dad9b86a870

subject: Change finish_resize paths to use objects

commit_message:
Change finish_resize paths to use objects

Converts calls to compute's finish_resize to pass new-world instance
and migration objects.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: Ic513b826087ced39c8aa939e93fe6c0d250dc1a5

commit_message:
Introduces The Guru Meditation Report

Introduces the classes for the actual Guru Meditation Report,
and utilities for creating a hook to autorun it on SIGUSR1.
The Text version is introduced in this commit; it is called
TextGuruMeditation.  This is the last of the Guru Meditation
Report/Openstack Common Reporting Framework commits.

Change-Id: I89cf868c0b515b6caf20987bfa2d6b73c860672a
Implements: bp guru-meditation-report

commit_message:
Adding IPsec site connection to Heat resources

Adds Neutron IPsec site connection component to resources
supported by Heat with unit tests.

Change-Id: Idf3c92b9a7ac513e7f7ab0d2501668405189ebc6
Implements: blueprint vpnaas-support

Adding IPsec policy to Heat resources

Adds Neutron IPsec policy component to resources
supported by Heat with unit tests.

commit_message:
Adding IKE policy to Heat resources

Adds Neutron IKE policy component to resources
supported by Heat with unit tests.

Change-Id: I54a83aededc779ddcf44ce72b0a1bb2b69a26094
Implements: blueprint vpnaas-support

commit_message:
Adding VPN Service to Heat resources

Adds Neutron VPN service component to resources
supported by Heat with unit tests.

Change-Id: I3a626166253bcb33d8875cf406b293688f53ffa3
Implements: blueprint vpnaas-support

"}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-08-01 16:56:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The unhelpful pep8 error is due to the commit message. Your first line should be a short description of the change. "Implements blueprint xxxx" should come in the description.

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages#Summary_of_GIT_commit_message_structure

If this is a work in progress you might want to click the "Work in Progress" button to highlight this. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 6620, 'date': '2013-08-01 17:07:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

This blueprint is dependent on the Cisco N1K plugin being pushed up to Neutron. The review for that is at - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/34642/

Additionally, changes will be added to ensure the new dashboard can be turned on when the Cisco N1K plugin is detected and not otherwise.'}, {'account_id': 6620, 'date': '2013-08-01 17:09:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Julie. 
I've marked this as Work in Progress using the button.

I'll try to modify the message to to confirm to the expected format.
Thanks for your quick comment on this!"}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-08-01 17:11:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

No problems. You can run "./run_tests -p" locally to check that the new commit message fixes the issue.

For reference I filed a bug about the unclear pep8 error at https://bugs.launchpad.net/hacking/+bug/1194180 .'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-09 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:
