[{'created': '2013-05-13 14:22:57.000000000', 'message': 'Replaces evzookeeper with kazoo

Kazoo is a pure Python implementation of Zookeeper client.
It is deloped more actively and does not require C bindings.
Membership function is provided directly by Zookeeper, implemented
using ephemeral nodes.

Change-Id: I7b486d6a564f93bf19d66acc04dd9b73701fa942

Membership function is provided directly by Zookeeper, implemented
using ephemeral nodes.

Change-Id: I7b486d6a564f93bf19d66acc04dd9b73701fa942
Implements: blueprint evzookeeper-kazoo
'}]
commit_message:
Add Kazoo-powered servicegroup driver for Zookeeper

Kazoo is a pure Python implementation of Zookeeper client.
It is developed more actively and does not require C bindings.
Membership function is provided directly by Zookeeper, implemented
using ephemeral nodes.

Change-Id: I7b486d6a564f93bf19d66acc04dd9b73701fa942
Implements: blueprint evzookeeper-kazoo

commit_message:
VMware: enable VNC access without user having to enter password

When the vnc_password was not configured in the 'vmware' section
the user was unable to access the VNC console. The user would be
requested to enter a password but all attempts would fail.

The 'nvc_password' was added as a workaround to the problem above.

The fix ensures that the VMware driver behaves like all of the other
virt drivers when it comes to the VNC access, that is, the user will
not have to enter a password.

The password support will be deprecated and removed in the next
version.

Fixes bug: 1215352

(cherry picked from commit 7659058fad03201e41461418568797d1591067e7)

Change-Id: I04b59b39f66b5844bf6399051e7e328bea79e513

commit_message:
Retry a chunk upload during Glance upload vhd

On a timeout exception, the chunk upload is retried using the
same connection.

Related to bp retry-a-chunk-upload-for-timeout-errors

Change-Id: Iffd0b5c819ec1b28dcef038cf83ac1e1b3d4f5fd

This implementation of the store backend mounts remote resources over NFS. However, I do not see any code that unmounts mounted shares. If i'm wrong and there's another component of Glance that carries about unmounting, please just point me to it.

My second question is what happens, if Glance crashes after mounting the remote NFS share? AFAIR it will never get unmounted. This has to be fixed."}, {'account_id': 6623, 'date': '2013-08-05 08:29:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 7711, 'date': '2013-08-05 08:49:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

NFS mount uses 'hard' mode by default (see man pages). It supposes that a work thread will be blocked on I/O indefinite time in case of network error. What we must do at this case?
I think we must forced 'soft' mode mount for correct error handling."}, {'account_id': 7534, 'date': '2013-08-05 09:09:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

In connection to your question about mount mode
"NFS mount uses 'hard' mode by default (see man pages). It supposes that a work thread will be blocked on I/O indefinite time in case of network error. What we must do at this case? I think we must forced 'soft' mode mount for correct error handling."

I agree with you. Default option will be "-o soft"'}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-05 10:51:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

You asked about share unmount:
"This implementation of the store backend mounts remote resources over NFS. However, I do not see any code that unmounts mounted shares... My second question is what happens, if Glance crashes after mounting the remote NFS share? AFAIR it will never get unmounted. This has to be fixed."

There are some reasons why store doesn't unmount share:
1. Glance uses only one share+mount_point and in case crash and restart, the same share will be used. No any leaks.
2. Nfs share is a system object and can be mounted or unmounted by any other then the Glance, if it needs.
3. Glance doesn't mount many shares (for example in loop) so no resources be leak
4. Nfs share unmounting is a very long operation and hasn't been performed in destructor
5. Share unmount hasn't be performed after mounting because both operations need too many time.'}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-05 12:44:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 7491, 'date': '2013-08-05 13:14:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hello Valerii Zhelezniakov, thanks for your work.


1. For configuration template change, you'd better also address follow files:
doc/source/configuring.rst
etc/glance-cache.conf


2. IMO, I also consider import 'rootwrap' for this store will be better, to prevent potential security issue.


3. From my perspective, under your implement the nfs-driver is a "auto-mounting" + "file-store", TBH i'm not sure the unique value it provided. Under current deployment without nfs-store, admin can manually mount nfs to glance-api host and using file-store directly.


4. Under current implement, I don't think support unmount is a good idea, since it probable put a concurrent issue under multiple glance-api process environment. think about one process doing 'get_size()' and other process doing 'get()' on a same image.'}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-06 12:35:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (6 inline comments)

>>"1. For configuration template change, you'd better also address follow files: doc/source/configuring.rst etc/glance-cache.conf"


Document "doc/source/configuring.rst" was updated


>>>"2. IMO, I also consider import 'rootwrap' for this store will be better, to prevent potential security issue."


We imported 'rootwrap' from OSLO. Link to patch related to 'rootwrap' is: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/39698/


>>>"3. From my perspective, under your implement the nfs-driver is a "auto-mounting" + "file-store", TBH i'm not sure the unique value it provided. Under current deployment without nfs-store, admin can manually mount nfs to glance-api host and using file-store directly."


The main goal of patch is making NFS as efficient backend for Glance. After implementation Glance will be report the direct URL for images stored on NFS storage, so that clients (such as Cinder) will be able to read the image data directly from the storage backend without placing Glance in the data path.


>>>"4. Under current implement, I don't think support unmount is a good idea, since it probable put a concurrent issue under multiple glance-api process environment. think about one process doing 'get_size()' and other process doing 'get()' on a same image."


Agree with you. We will not implement unmount operation.'}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-06 12:38:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-06 13:33:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Works for me

Zhi Yan Liu: sorry for the delay in the response'}, {'account_id': 6623, 'date': '2013-08-07 12:31:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

A few minor nits in the commit message.

Although I do not like the idea that there's no way to unmount the share, the code corresponds to the hacking guidelines more or less so I will be happy to +1 the patch as soon as Glance core team agrees with the policy of a persistent mounting.

Currently the administrator can set up fstab file on a NFS node to mount the remote filesystem on start up. This patch brings just one tiny feature that allows mounting shares on demand. However, this tiny feature adds an unreasonable amount complexity for supporting it: i.e. additional parameters for deploy options require additional deployment tests to be written, etc.

Managing mounting AND unmounting NFS shares automatically is what will make this feature worth the added complexity in supporting it. There might be several kinds of problems like stale file handles, etc. Problems like that still need to be fixed manually by an administrator which is not correct IMO."}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-08-07 14:50:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-08-07 15:04:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Hello Valerii, one inline comment."}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-07 15:29:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: (1 inline comment)

Hi Zhi Yan Liu,

I understand you, and implement it as soon as possible.'}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-07 15:31:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2013-08-08 09:47:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Last time a specific Glance backend was proposed that required to introduce rootwrap to Glance, it was rejected and the recommendation was to grow a generic Cinder backend support instead.

I still think that's the right way of proceeding, I'd hate to see rootwrap being used on a project that should not require it (and I authored the damn thing).

See my comment on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/39698/ for how to handle the root_helper parameter better."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-08-09 07:24:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hey,

I agree with Thierry with regard to using rootwrap for this project. 

Also, do we really need this back-end? Why can't the user mount the share himself and use the filesystem store instead?"}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-09 12:05:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

Thanks a lot for reviewing and comments.


@Roman Prykhodchenko
We will not be able to support mount and unmount feature, because we are planning to remove using rootwrap.


@Zhi Yan Liu 
We are working on supporting multi-share of NFS targets. It will be available soon.


@Thierry Carrez
I will remove rootwrap. Absolutely agree with you - it could bring security issue.
In such case administrator can mount NFS share by himself. Then put shares' URL and mount points to glance-api.conf.
Using this case we put the responsibility of mounting share on Administrator.
The limitation is that share can't be auto mounted in code, e.g. if something happens with connection only administrator can mount it again.


@Flavio Percoco
The main idea of this patch is to improve process of working between Glance and Cinder if they are both using the same NFS backend.
Glance will report the direct URL for images stored on NFS storage, so that clients (such as Cinder) will be able to read the image data directly from the storage backend without downloading image from Glance.


Without NFS Store backend Glance cannot report the NFS direct URL to client (eg. Nova, Cinder). So we can not have a full support of NFS in the OpenStak and therefore full-power using devices that support NFS in production clusters  (eg. FAS/NAS devices)."}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-08-09 14:42:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

Hello Valerii, I'd like to check your next PS which including the changes you mentioned in above comments.

And under the description in your above comments, I have some concerns. If nfs-driver code not do mounting and unmounting, and need administrator take that responsibility manually, then IMO this driver just is a "file-store with a NFS mountpoint/directory (filesystem_store_datadir option)". 

I know you want to allow glance client such as cinder or nova get the NFS info from image's directl_url (locations AKA), but you can use file-store's metadata to do the similar things, pls refer: https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/store/filesystem.py#L43'}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-09 15:20:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

Hello Zhi,


I will upload patch today.
About your concern. It's a good point, but this case allows us to have only one shared storage configured and mounted. So we will be limited in using one storage. Based on previous discussions we decided to have multi-shared storages support."}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-09 16:14:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-09 16:21:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

- multi-share supporting was added

- rootwrap was removed (automount was removed too)

- unit-tests were updated'}, {'account_id': 6493, 'date': '2013-08-09 17:02:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Valerii,

I think having an NFS storage backend has value, but I want to address your point about not being able to share a direct URL without it.  Recently we added the notion of 'meta-data' that describes each direct URL that glance advertises.  This gives the storage system a place to add context (such as contact information for a NFS server).  So for example, the direct URL maybe file:///opt/glance/images/fedora.qcow2 and the meta-data {'filesystem': 'NFS', 'ID': 'xyz', 'mountpoint': '/opt'} etc.  There is a patch in nova that already makes use to this.

In that light I would like to hear the added value of a NFS specific driver.  My concern is that more code means more maintenance."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-09 17:07:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Works for me

"}, {'account_id': 8391, 'date': '2013-08-09 17:42:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

John thanks for the comment.
Yes, we've seen notion of 'meta-data'. As far as I understand, we can set only one path to data directory for Filesystem store.
In such case we can have only one share for storing images.
So I don't see possibility to use 'meta-data' for multi-shares. If I'm wrong, please correct me."}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-08-10 04:07:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

Vasiliy, an image can have multiple locations, and each location can has a metadata. Such as an image has 2 different  locations and its dedicated metadata:

file:///opt/glance/images/fedora.qcow2 and the meta-data {'filesystem': 'NFS', 'ID': 'xyz', 'mountpoint': '/opt'}

file:///mnt/glance/images/fedora.qcow2 and the meta-data {'filesystem': 'NFS', 'ID': 'abc', 'mountpoint': '/mnt'}

This is a work on practice level for user but code level, user can adding new location with its metadata to an existing image by Glance v2 PATCH API."}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-12 11:07:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-08-12 11:07:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

Added some inline comments. And I'm also interested in your result about using file-store+metadata for cinder direct consuming."}, {'account_id': 7711, 'date': '2013-08-13 08:03:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

Two remarks:

1. Assume that I have two devices: new NAS from my favorite brand with 10GbE and old with 1GbE. I would like to have feature to set priority on the first.

2. Multi-share feature is not implemented for filesystem store in glance. May be better to do it there.'}, {'account_id': 8391, 'date': '2013-08-15 13:31:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

Hi Zhi Yan Liu and John Bresnahan.

We have tested using Glance FileSystem backend for NFS with Cinder and Nova. And it looks workable for NFS backend.

Solution of using 'meta data' works for accessing images directly from clients.

The format we used for testing is:
{
	"share_location": "nfs://host/path",
	"mount_point": "/opt/stack/data/glance",
	"type": "nfs"
}


So, any way this patch "NFS Backend for Glance" will have advantages of using multi-shares as:
- algorithm of selection optimal shared storages for adding new images
- reservation mechanism of available space on disc
- possibility to set priority for shares
- moderately easier for administrators to setup NFS backend, than using 'meta data' solution.'}, {'account_id': 8391, 'date': '2013-08-16 15:29:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19:

From IRC-chat by 15-August-2013

<markwash> we added a feature recently to support multiple image locations--an image can --- share with the client that it is stored in multiple places and where those places are the idea sounds similar to multishares, except broader than nfs

<markwash> so if you store something in both, say, cinder, and swift, the client --- can pick which one

<markwash> or if you store an image in two swift endpoints on different systems, --- the client can pick which one if he wants to do a direct download

<markwash> we haven't quite gotten that far, but it would be possible to start streaming to multiple locations on an upload

<markwash> or some sort of multi-locations setup based on policy/config


First of all I'd like to say that multi-shares and multiple image locations are different things.
To have multiple image locations is advantage for us to have reliability of data storage. Our patch will add scalability. The problem of lack of space in the storage will be decided by simple mounting of another shared storage.

Multi-location is a top level of architecture which allows to save images in diferent locations. Our patch has lower level - it's driver level. On the top level is not easy to perform tasks such as: increasing the storage capacity, increase performance. We propose to make the driver for easily scalable and flexibly configurable NFS devices, which Glance storage can use if you want to easy control the amount of storage and performance."}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-16 16:03:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-16 16:03:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: (5 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-16 16:04:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

I added following features to my patch set:
- algorithm of selection optimal shared storages for adding new images
- reservation mechanism of available space on disc
- possibility to set priority for the shares'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-16 18:01:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/80/39080/20/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-testr-full/83e6cc5 : FAILURE in 32m 11s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/80/39080/20/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/5a5adda : SUCCESS in 46m 17s
- http://logs.openstack.org/80/39080/20/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron/5b6f198 : SUCCESS in 18m 30s
- http://logs.openstack.org/80/39080/20/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/08e9f7f : SUCCESS in 28m 54s
'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-08-17 05:37:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(8 inline comments)

I added some inline comments.

TBH I can agree your views personally, I consider multi-location and multi-shares are all resolving the scalability but from different approach. Of cause currently multi-location miss something then multi-shares. But do you think follow three parts should be addressed on top level of architecture also? It will be better then we handle it on low/particular driver level, since they are common requirement for image management:
1. algorithm of selection optimal shared storages for adding new images.
2. reservation mechanism of available space on disc.
3. possibility to set priority for shares.
Acutally I'd prefer add above enhancement to glance at high level but particular driver, this can give benefit to all backend store but nfs only. And this should be covered by a dedicate bp."}, {'account_id': 7711, 'date': '2013-08-19 09:10:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

Right direction, and I will be happy +1"}, {'account_id': 7711, 'date': '2013-08-19 09:40:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 8291, 'date': '2013-08-19 14:39:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: (9 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-08-19 18:38:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Do not merge

Blueprint not approved'}, {'account_id': 6493, 'date': '2013-08-22 08:09:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

I wonder if this patch would be a good example of the need for https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/framework-for-contributed-storage-systems.  A lot of work went into this patch and it could be useful in some places, however is not yet approved for glance.  Were there to be an easy recipe for creating such systems outside of the Glance distribution yet installing them into it the gap might be bridged.  Just food for thought.'}, {'account_id': 8391, 'date': '2013-08-27 16:32:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

Hi John - thanks for the link to blueprint. We will try to contribute on it during development of Icehouse :)'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-09-04 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-09-04 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-29 13:57:46.000000000', 'message': "Added Glance NFS Storage support.

NFS Storage for Glance was created.
Implementation includes:
- Store and StoreLocation classes in nfs.py
- Unit tests for the Glance NFS backend in test_nfs_store.py
- Rootwrap extension

The NFS backend uses 'mount.nfs' for mounting remote NFS share.
All needed parameters were included to Glance configuration.
Share mounting are performed by Glance on any request to image.
IPv6 addresses are supported.

Change-Id: I390565165c7ec856c0b7e7051e26938b3fc2f6a6
Implements: blueprint glance-nfs-storage-support

- Store and StoreLocation classes in nfs.py
- Unit tests for Glance NFS backend in test_nfs_store.py

The main idea of this patch is to improve process of working between Glance and Cinder if they are both using the same NFS backend. Glance will report the direct URL for images stored on NFS storage, so that clients (such as Cinder) will be able to read the image data directly from the storage backend without downloading image from Glance.

Without NFS Store backend Glance cannot report the NFS direct URL to client (eg. Nova, Cinder). So we can not have a full support of NFS in the OpenStak and therefore full-power using devices that support NFS in production clusters (eg. FAS/NAS devices).

Implements: blueprint glance-nfs-storage-support

Change-Id: I390565165c7ec856c0b7e7051e26938b3fc2f6a6

commit_message:
Add Glance NFS Storage support

NFS Storage backend for Glance was created.
Implementation includes:
- Store and StoreLocation classes in nfs.py
- Unit tests for Glance NFS backend in test_nfs_store.py

The main idea of this patch is to improve process of working between Glance
and Cinder if they are both using the same NFS backend. Glance will report the
direct URL for images stored on NFS storage, so that clients (such as Cinder)
will be able to read the image data directly from the storage backend without
downloading image from Glance.

Without NFS Store backend Glance cannot report the NFS direct URL to client
(eg. Nova, Cinder). So we can not have a full support of NFS in the OpenStak
and therefore full-power using devices that support NFS in production clusters
(eg. FAS/NAS devices).

Implements: blueprint glance-nfs-storage-support

Change-Id: I390565165c7ec856c0b7e7051e26938b3fc2f6a6

subject: Switch from cinder.quota to common.quota

"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-08-13 14:07:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm not convinced that all of this can be done by putting data in extra_specs at the moment.  For example take the isolated_hosts filter - this would need to be a list of host names which normally would never be exposed to users, but there may be other reasons that other aspects of extra_specs do need to be exposed - and the favorextraspecs extension doesn't have any granularity.

Can't this all be done by constraining a flavor to an aggregate and setting all of the scheduler parameters on the aggregate (which is then abstracted away from users)"}, {'account_id': 2667, 'date': '2013-08-13 15:57:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

@Phil: Thanks for the comments. 

1) Agree that granularity in surfacing flavor extra specs could make sense going forward. However, it doesn't seem to be  *mandatory* to make the capability added by this patch useful -- the admin can still decide to hide all the flavor extra specs altogether. 

2) regarding "setting all of the scheduler parameters on the aggregate" -- this was part of the original proposal, a few patchsets back.. The problem with this approach is that the way scheduler works today, aggregates are currently considered as part of host selection, *after* driver and filters are selected. Making this work differently (e.g., two-step process - first select aggregate and then host) would require a significant redesign, which is beyond the scope of what we are targeting for Havana.'}, {'account_id': 7238, 'date': '2013-08-14 10:05:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 25.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-14 10:58:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-08-14 11:16:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

@Alex:

Agree that showing extra spec isn't mandatory, but their may be cloud providers already locked into having to show extra specs to their users, so a change that potentially adds non-user facing data into extra-spec without proving any additional control on what is visible seems broken to me.

I think that bigger point here though is that things like "cpu allocation ratio" are things that belong to an aggregates that need to be mutually exclusive in the sets of hosts that they include.  So I don't see that the current approach of getting this data as as part of the hist selection  is an issue.   Making it part of flavor, which seems to imply that from a data model perspective different instances on the same host could be using different values of cpu or memory over commit just seems the wrong place to have this kind of information.'}, {'account_id': 2667, 'date': '2013-08-14 11:54:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25: (5 inline comments)

few minor comments inline'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-08-15 10:12:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25:

Sorry - really confused now.   The commit message talks about overriding scheduler parameters like filter lists, via flavor extra specs, but the changes seem to be picking up detailed values for the scheduler filters from the new Policy driver.

I tried going back and reading the BP and wiki page, but that still refers to passing in policies as part of scheduler hits, so it wasn't much help.

I think I understand what you're trying to achieve - have different scheduler configurations for different pools of hosts (aggregates) - but i'm really struggling to see how this leads to that.  As currently constructed it looks like different requests could be scheduled using different policies to the same set of hosts - which doesn't make sense to me (how can something like memory over-commit vary on a host) ?

Maybe it just needs the BP/wiki updating to align with the code and it will all become clear ?"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-08-19 19:50:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 26: No score

Phil: you're right that the use of flavor extra specs leads to the possibility of configurations that make no sense (different overcommit ratios for scheduling instances that end up on the same host).  There is an assumption that this is used in combination with the ability to limit a flavor to an aggregate using an additional extra_spec for cases where it is important to do so.  The docs could probably be updated to clarify that further."}, {'account_id': 7238, 'date': '2013-08-20 12:44:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 27.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-08-20 13:09:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 27: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-08-22 16:52:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 28: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Thanks to Alex for updating the wiki, that made it a lot clearer.   However it still feels to me that we're doing too much in the flavor rather than the aggregate.  Looking at the wiki I have to:

1) Create the aggregate
2) Map flavors to that aggregate
3) Add *the same* scheduling parameters to every flavor I map into the aggregate via "sched:" extra_specs

Its step 3 that seems wrong and unnecessary to me.   There is no reason I can thin of where I would want multiple flavors
that I'm mapping into the aggregate to have different cpu_allocation_ratios, and I can define that value already as part of the aggregate metadata if I use the right filters.    So what do we gain by replicating these per-aggregate scheduling settings in multiple flavors ?   

Seems to me we're just creating work and possible errors for something that can already be handled today via aggregate metadata'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-08-22 20:47:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 28:

The issue is how early these parameters need to be interpreted.  The mapping of a flavor to an aggregate is something that happens down inside of the filter scheduler.  This feature lets you choose a different scheduler driver completely if you wanted.  By the time we get down to the filtering based on aggregate, it's too late.

I suppose it could be done, but the way aggregates are processed in the scheduler would have to be *drastically* different than it is today.

In any case, I do want to see consensus on this before it goes in.  Perhaps we need to have another thread on the openstack-dev list about the current design?"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-08-22 20:48:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 28: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 2667, 'date': '2013-08-23 07:04:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 28: No score

Agree with Russell regarding potentially large change that would be required to process aggregates data early enough. We will consider it for Icehouse.
@Phil: small correction: you don't need to specify all sched parameters in all the flavors. Just those that you want to override. 
By the way, something like Tuskar could take care of automating the setting of all these parameters. That might be pretty neat.
Regarding consensus on ML -- I've sent an email on this on Tue, exactly for this purpose (continuing an older thread). Didn't see any responses, but if anyone is interested to highlight the dilemma (if there is still any) - that thread can be used for this purpose.
@Russell: will make the singleton a separate patch, thanks."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-08-23 15:43:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 28: No score

Hi Folks,

I do get the point that the selection of “Policy” needs to be ahead of the run through the filters, and agree that it makes sense for this to be a property of the flavour.   What I don’t like is the setting of details of that policy in the flavour, and the way it has to be replicated in each of the flvaours that are eventually going to be linked to an aggregate.   That just still feels really clunky and the wrong level of abstraction to me.

@Alex – I take your point that you only have to specify the parts of the policy you’re going to override, but as discussed already some of those setting it never makes sense to have different on two flavours that are targeted at the same aggregate – and we already have Imo a good way to doing things like cpu and ram allocation as aggregate metadata, and this seems to be leading people away from that.   Also if the overall policy comes from a combination of places its going to make working out what the aggregate policy that’s applied actually is. 

The BP says that the next step is for policies to be top level objects in their own rights, at which point we’d have what seems to be a better level of abstraction (i.e flavour -> policy -> detailed setting and/or aggregate)  - it just kind of feels that this first step is a bit clunky as an interim, and maybe painful to move away from.  I have this nagging doubt that we’re rushing at this because we don’t have time to do the policy objects properly.

So my personal preference would be to hold back until we can do a fuller implementation that includes better Policy management, which would also tie in with the Pcloud stuff.   

However, on the basis that I don’t have to use it if I don’t want to, that this is only an interim step, and assuming that there are some people that really have a demand for this in the current form (and we’re not just trying to tick a BP box for Havana) – I’ll shift to a 0 on this and let others decide.'}, {'account_id': 1782, 'date': '2013-08-25 12:56:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 29.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-25 13:18:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 29: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'created': '2013-07-31 22:41:38.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: multiple scheduler policies (drivers)

Support multiple active scheduler policies/configurations

Allows maintaining multiple active scheduler policies/configurations
within a single Nova deployment.
Each valid policy/configuration is specified in nova.conf, allowing to
override scheduler-related options such as driver, filters, etc. (note:
in the future, this is likely to be replaced with more dynamic,
API-driven, life cycle).

On instance provisioning, desired policy is chosen using corresponding
key-value in the flavor extra spec (note: in the future, additional
mechanisms for policy selection will be considered).
Also, optionally, a new filter can be used with FilterScheduler to
restrict applicable host aggregates to those specifying a matching
policy.

implements blueprint multiple-scheduler-drivers

DocImpact

Change-Id: I8bcd3e48d8047b0ff19c435c7c8ae49cdb24352f

commit_message:
Support multiple active scheduler policies/configurations

Allows maintaining multiple active scheduler policies/configurations
within a single Nova deployment.
Scheduler parameters (drivers, filters, options, etc) can be overridden
by specifying them in flavor extra spec, with "sched:" key namespace.

Partially implements blueprint multiple-scheduler-drivers

DocImpact

Change-Id: I8bcd3e48d8047b0ff19c435c7c8ae49cdb24352f

commit_message:
VMware: Add support for resource pool in VMware Drivers

Currently, VMware drivers boot instances in the root resource
pool of a compute resource (host or cluster). This patch allows
admins to specify a resource pool inside the compute resource.

Change-Id: I8cb6b2c6892743417e93235d506af1b2fda6b18c
Fixes: bug #1105032

commit_message:
renamed deprecated glanceclient parameter

According to the sources the parameter --public in python-glanceclient
should be removed after only using the new parameter --is-public in
Devstack.

Fixes: bug 1214094
Change-Id: I25fbb23f4823b3766db647dd50a5b538aad3e55a
(cherry picked from commit a7a219ab76d4a346f794daafd499ece5c32c5e3c)

[{'created': '2013-08-06 05:07:06.000000000', 'message': 'Adding glanceclient version

Nova should be configured to use glanceclient V1 or V2. Adds an extra
parameter in the conf to specify this value. Currently it is hardcoded
to 1 in all the glanceclient calls

Change-Id: I828d98ab6fd8bcf813c52276b79337f782482c94
Implements: blueprint glanceclient-version

commit_message:
Adding glanceclient version

Nova should be configured to use glanceclient V1 or V2. Adds an extra
parameter in the conf to specify this value. Currently it is hardcoded
to 1 in all the glanceclient calls

Change-Id: I828d98ab6fd8bcf813c52276b79337f782482c94
Implements: blueprint glanceclient-version

Puppet was not managing the parameter, but Keystone defaults to the following in Grizzly:

commit_message:
WIP: Adds Support to Manage SSL

The keystone class provides UUID and PKI token formats, but does
not provide the ability to manage SSL.  This patch introduces the
enable_ssl parameter that allows users to enable and disable SSL.

Defaults to false for backwards compatibility and to disable SSL.

Change-Id: If11e3eccf145b5f87e6c8979f42665577e35b50b

commit_message:
nova failures when vCenter has multiple datacenters

Calculates the datacenter that should be used when there
is more than one in a vCenter. Does not negatively
affect ESXi driver.

addresses bug/1180044

Change-Id: I7c4a763dc4f0c0e554d5b2c47faa233bed0d4c60

commit_message:
Add a prototype of reverting strategies

Have the linear flow call a strategy which can
attempt to alter how a individual task is reverted
before the full set of tasks is reverted. The current
example allows for retrying a task a number of times
before failing out all the tasks the flow has ran.

Part of: blueprint reversion-strategies

Change-Id: I44adc69dc9dea25bc611210bd0e6060f4dd100d5

commit_message:
Adds architecture param to create-nodes script

If someone builds 64bit seed/undercloud/overcloud images with
diskimagebuilder, then there would be an arch mismatch because
create-nodes sets i686 architecture when creating VMs in libvirt.

Change-Id: Ic13c2fd954deb3a5bc5faa1528fe81e5f993a0fe
Fixes: bug #1216864

commit_message:
Include oslo.config=1.2.0a3 for trove guest VM

python dependencies were being installed
(including oslo.config) before we install
trove inside guest VM,therefore the
oslo.config>=1.2.0a3 was not picked
 up from trove requirements.txt.
The same has been addressed here.

Fixes: bug #1215001

Change-Id: I75d976ebaac868e0ef27f4891d19c13502bd23d0

commit_message:
Show example of unification

Instead of keeping the existing flows with there functionality
move the existing flows to just be the thing that defines the
runtime structure. Have the action_engine translate these
structures into something useful, which in the case of action_engine
is translating the structures into things that are pretty much
like the existing flows (but not exactly).

Change-Id: I19b2992644ab2233731cbfd458e34d40cc84850e

[{'created': '2013-09-03 18:40:28.000000000', 'message': 'Verify MTU is valid for ipsec_site_connection

Since the check relies on the vpnservice subnet to determine whether this
is IPv4 ro IPv6, we must check in the plugin. Test is done at create/update
time and ensures that the MTU is equal to or greater than the minimum allowed
values, which are set to 68 for IPv4 minimum and 1280 for IPv6, respectively.

Refactored code to allow reuse of create and update test functions, by
allowing tests to override some settings, and to provide a dict of changed
items (for update).

bug 1219489

commit_message:
Verify MTU is valid for ipsec_site_connection

Since the check relies on the vpnservice subnet to determine whether
this is IPv4 ro IPv6, we must check in the plugin. Test is done at
create/update time and ensures that the MTU is equal to or greater
than the minimum allowed values, which are set to 68 for IPv4
minimum and 1280 for IPv6, respectively.

Refactored code to allow reuse of create and update test functions,
by allowing tests to override some settings, and to provide a dict
of changed items (for update).

bug 1219489

Change-Id: I3e62ef786d3a02c761903a15d546ee8758c0bf7f

commit_message:
Add a oauth1-configuration.rst and extension section to docs

The patch addresses the following:
1) Add an extensions section to the configuration.rst
2) Add the oauth-configuration.rst to the previously mentioned
section.

fixes bug: #1218722

Change-Id: I0c832d89698fc43a19408e8e7c159f09e0ec5e15

commit_message:
Implement ML2 port binding

The ml2 plugin uses mechanism drivers to determine which network
segment and what VIF driver to use for a port. Mechanism drivers
supporting the openvswitch, linuxbridge, and hyperv agents are
added. The binding:host attribute is set on ports belonging to the
dhcp and l3 agents so that they can be bound.

To use with devstack until it is updated, set
"Q_ML2_PLUGIN_MECHANISM_DRIVERS=openvswitch,linuxbridge" in localrc.

The hyperv L2 agent does not currently implement the agents_db RPC,
and will therefore not work with its ml2 mechanism driver. This issue
will be tracked as a bug to be fixed in a separate merge.

implements blueprint: ml2-portbinding

Change-Id: Icb9c70d8b0d7fcb34b57adc760bb713b740e5dad

and pasting the output.

commit_message:
Have tox install via setup.py develop

tox 1.6 was released, which means that we can now take advantage of the
feature we added to it - which is using setup.py develop to install the
code into the virtualenv. The logic was taken from run_tests.sh - so the
performance issues around using tox vs. using install_venv should now be
gone.

run_tests.sh is still needed to handle the ui switching between
parallel, single and debug modes to testr.

Change-Id: Ida5e440d1bdb9f8e9031277ea53a02d2ef171438

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-26 19:50:27.000000000', 'message': 'Utilities to create directores, set ownership & permissions

Add the get_unix_user(), get_unix_group(), set_permissions(),
make_dirs() utilities to keystone/common/utils.py. These functions are
much more robust and flexible. Ownership can be specifed either with
symbolic names or explicit id's. Any value you do not want to override
can be passed as None and it will be skipped.

The BaseCertificateConfigure class in openssl.py had it's own code to
create directories, set ownership, set permissions, etc. which was
used for setting up certificates, key files, etc. Properly handling
file system objects should not be a property of openssl, rather these
should be general utilities which can be used in a variety of
locations. Plus the openssl versions were not fully general and had
some pecular limitations. The new utilies will be used in a subsequent
patch which also needs this functionality but isn't in openssl code.

Previously the openssl code was inconsistent as to whether it set the
ownership and permissions, sometimes ownership and permission was set
only if the file/dir did not exist, other times the ownership and
permission were set irregardless of prior existence. The modified code
now always sets ownerhip and permissions (if provided).

The prior code assumed an id (uid/gid) was being passed for ownership,
but this was not documented. The code appears to take a symbolic
name. The cli code converted symbolic names passed on the command line
to id's before instantiating a class which accepts ownership
information. If you instantiated one of the class without first
converting a name to an id it would throw an exception. The new
utilities accept either symbolic names or id's and since these
utilities are now used internally you can pass either a name or id and
one is no longer dependent upon special handling inside cli argument
parsing code to get correct behavior with these classes.

There were several places with code like this:

    os.chown(file_name, self.use_keystone_user or -1,
             self.use_keystone_group or -1)

The intent would appear to be to avoid setting the uid or gid if the
attribute had a value of None. Except this fails completely if the
uid or gid belongs to root because those id's are zero, thus the code
would never work with root id's. The new utilities explicitly test for
a value of None and do not rely on the weak "truth test".

Note: these new utilities are intended to be moved into oslo-incubator
in the near future.

Fixes: bug #1206254

Change-Id: I34b811513ebfd48d91600051724949c0a96c0734

commit_message:
Utilities to create directores, set ownership & permissions

Add the get_unix_user(), get_unix_group(), set_permissions(),
make_dirs() utilities to keystone/common/utils.py. These functions are
much more robust and flexible. Ownership can be specifed either with
symbolic names or explicit id's. Any value you do not want to override
can be passed as None and it will be skipped.

The BaseCertificateConfigure class in openssl.py had it's own code to
create directories, set ownership, set permissions, etc. which was
used for setting up certificates, key files, etc. Properly handling
file system objects should not be a property of openssl, rather these
should be general utilities which can be used in a variety of
locations. Plus the openssl versions were not fully general and had
some pecular limitations. The new utilies will be used in a subsequent
patch which also needs this functionality but isn't in openssl code.

Previously the openssl code was inconsistent as to whether it set the
ownership and permissions, sometimes ownership and permission was set
only if the file/dir did not exist, other times the ownership and
permission were set irregardless of prior existence. The modified code
now always sets ownerhip and permissions (if provided).

The prior code assumed an id (uid/gid) was being passed for ownership,
but this was not documented. The code appears to take a symbolic
name. The cli code converted symbolic names passed on the command line
to id's before instantiating a class which accepts ownership
information. If you instantiated one of the class without first
converting a name to an id it would throw an exception. The new
utilities accept either symbolic names or id's and since these
utilities are now used internally you can pass either a name or id and
one is no longer dependent upon special handling inside cli argument
parsing code to get correct behavior with these classes.

There were several places with code like this:

    os.chown(file_name, self.use_keystone_user or -1,
             self.use_keystone_group or -1)

The intent would appear to be to avoid setting the uid or gid if the
attribute had a value of None. Except this fails completely if the
uid or gid belongs to root because those id's are zero, thus the code
would never work with root id's. The new utilities explicitly test for
a value of None and do not rely on the weak "truth test".

Note: these new utilities are intended to be moved into oslo-incubator
in the near future.

Fixes: bug #1206254

Change-Id: I34b811513ebfd48d91600051724949c0a96c0734

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-29 20:01:43.000000000', 'message': 'Support Security Group Name Prefix Customization

As of now, if CONF.trove_security_groups_support == True, then a
Security Group is created for every new Instance, following the
naming scheme of: "SecGroup_<Instance's UUID>".
Nicira NVP for Quantum enforces a Security Group naming limitation of
40 chars maximum. Given the UUID's length, this only leaves 2
characters for the prefix, e.g. 'SG' vs. 'SecGroup'.
Even in lieu of restrictions, it's not inconceivable that a
vendor/user might want to customize the naming scheme of their
Security Groups to align with other cloud providers, etc.

Change-Id: I1043e15c71607cabe2fd6f72f64705e80cd2cde1
Closes-Bug: #1218589

commit_message:
Support Security Group Name Prefix Customization

As of now, if CONF.trove_security_groups_support == True, then a
Security Group is created for every new Instance, following the
naming scheme of: "SecGroup_<Instance's UUID>".

Nicira NVP for Quantum enforces a Security Group naming limitation of
40 chars maximum. Given the UUID's length, this only leaves 2
characters for the prefix, e.g. 'SG' vs. 'SecGroup'.

Even in lieu of restrictions, it's not inconceivable that a
vendor/user might want to customize the naming scheme of their
Security Groups to align with other cloud providers, etc.

Change-Id: I1043e15c71607cabe2fd6f72f64705e80cd2cde1
Closes-Bug: #1218589

commit_message:
Authorizing user should propose roles to delegate for OAuth

Currently in the oauth1 extension the consumer specifies roles
instead of delegator. This is a design fault that should be fixed
by having the authorizing user provide a set of roles (ids)
during the authorize request token phase

fixes bug: #1216408

commit_message:
Modify default file/directory permissions

* Remove execute permission on regular files (PRIV_PERMS).
* Create file mode constants for public/private directory/file.
* Grant read access to group members for files/directores marked private.

Change-Id: I92563a125e6ac93762db5fda65412f9a68ef35e3
Fixes: bug #1206254

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-31 02:57:15.000000000', 'message': "Custom Guest Log Directory Causes Init Failure

The log_dir in trove-guestagent.conf.sample currently defaults to
'/tmp', and the log_file to 'logfile.txt'.

If the log_dir value is changed to, say, '/var/log/trove', guest
initialization will fail because the directory does not exist. Even
if log_dir is set to '/var/log', initialization will fail due to
insufficient write permissions in said directory.

Solution: The log_dir specified in trove-guestagent.conf.sample
should be created on-demand if necessary.

Change-Id: Ic819aaa08f8a78483e1c0ae0aa8af370c6705562
Closes-Bug: #1219137
"}, {'created': '2013-09-04 00:53:32.000000000', 'message': "Custom Guest Log Directory Causes Init Failure

The log_dir in trove-guestagent.conf.sample currently defaults to
'/tmp', and the log_file to 'logfile.txt'.

If the log_dir value is changed to, say, '/var/log/trove', guest
initialization will fail because the directory does not exist. Even
if log_dir is set to '/var/log', initialization will fail due to
insufficient write permissions in said directory.

Solution: The log_dir specified in trove-guestagent.conf.sample
should be created on-demand if necessary.

Change-Id: Ic819aaa08f8a78483e1c0ae0aa8af370c6705562
Closes-Bug: #1219137
"}]
commit_message:
Custom Guest Log Directory Causes Init Failure

The log_dir in trove-guestagent.conf.sample currently defaults to
'/tmp', and the log_file to 'logfile.txt'.

If the log_dir value is changed to, say, '/var/log/trove', guest
initialization will fail because the directory does not exist. Even
if log_dir is set to '/var/log', initialization will fail due to
insufficient write permissions in said directory.

Solution: The log_dir specified in trove-guestagent.conf.sample
should be created on-demand if necessary.

Change-Id: Ic819aaa08f8a78483e1c0ae0aa8af370c6705562
Closes-Bug: #1219137

'}, {'created': '2013-08-26 19:22:22.000000000', 'message': "Improve EC2 API error responses

responses that makes finishing touches.

Useless EC2APIError exception is finally annihilated. Nova exceptions

commit_message:
Improve EC2 API error responses

This is a final patch from series of patches improving EC2 error
responses that makes finishing touches.

Useless EC2APIError exception is finally annihilated. Nova exceptions
that were raised outside of EC2 API are now translated to appropriate
EC2 error codes using ec2_code attribute.

With EC2 exceptions fixed, HTTP status code corresponding to raised
exception is now returned instead of previously hardcoded 400. All
expected exceptions are treated as client errors and returned with 4xx
HTTP status code for compatibility with EC2 API.

Unexpected exceptions are now always logged on ERROR log level, CRITICAL
wasn't really appropriate.

Following valid EC2 error codes were added to existing exceptions
eliminating the need to translate them explicitly:

 * InvalidKeypair.ec2_code = 'InvalidKeyPair.Format'
 * KeyPairExists.ec2_code = 'InvalidKeyPair.Duplicate'
 * QuotaError.ec2_code = 'ResourceLimitExceeded'
   (*LimitExceeded exceptions inherit from QuotaError)

Exceptions caught in Executor were reordered for better readability.

Implements: blueprint ec2-error-codes

Change-Id: I27f9397d006f1b66b53a91b04ec6763a4d8ac740

commit_message:
Include oslo.config=1.2.0a3 for trove guest VM

python dependencies were being installed
(including oslo.config) before we install
trove inside guest VM,therefore the
oslo.config>=1.2.0a3 was not picked
 up from trove requirements.txt.
The same has been addressed here.

Change-Id: I5047594827bcc3f9f2e0d909d6e9c24f57d4fd19
Fixes: bug #1215001

[{'created': '2013-09-03 15:33:25.000000000', 'message': 'Make error message for InvalidTemplateReference sane

Previously it was more or less incomprehensible. Now it will report the
non-existent resource the uesr tried to reference and the path (starting
with Resources) in the JSON document where the error occurred.

Change-Id: Id98eb4157df16674b8c8a9a190b82ee350c5386f
'}]
commit_message:
Make error message for InvalidTemplateReference sane

Previously it was more or less incomprehensible. Now it will report the
non-existent resource the uesr tried to reference and the path (starting
with Resources) in the JSON document where the error occurred.

Change-Id: Id98eb4157df16674b8c8a9a190b82ee350c5386f

[{'created': '2013-08-29 14:40:18.000000000', 'message': 'Be backward compatible after a renaming in API

The need was introduced with the renaming of field logical_resource_id
to resource_name, so let heatclient display the good one for the two
Heat versions.

Fixes bug #1216903

Change-Id: I3e86f482a1b814a27b15be3c102727c44153221f
'}]
commit_message:
Be backward compatible after a renaming in API

The need was introduced with the renaming of field logical_resource_id
to resource_name, so let heatclient display the good one for the two
Heat versions.

Fixes bug #1216903

Change-Id: I3e86f482a1b814a27b15be3c102727c44153221f

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-04 00:32:10.000000000', 'message': 'Added support for running the tests under PyPy with tox

This is a precursor to having them run under check and gate.

This also fixes a single test which fails on PyPy, the test failes at
because it assumes a ``dict`` has a particular order for its keys when
it is printed out, on PyPy dicts have a different order sometimes, the
exact ordering is not a guarnteed property of Python.

Change-Id: Ie86726a0221e5e9aa68f7303d8ca8c7acd878f65
'}]
commit_message:
Added support for running the tests under PyPy with tox

This is a precursor to having them run under check and gate.

This also fixes a single test which fails on PyPy, the test failes at
because it assumes a ``dict`` has a particular order for its keys when
it is printed out, on PyPy dicts have a different order sometimes, the
exact ordering is not a guarnteed property of Python.

Change-Id: Ie86726a0221e5e9aa68f7303d8ca8c7acd878f65

Remove a couple of unused stubs

Found a couple of unused stub functions in API fakes when grepping for
something else related to volumes.  Remove these.

Adding unit test code for rest api layer to enable support for
task operation.
Partially implement blueprint async-glance-workers

'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2013-08-19 23:00:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

I was talking to John about the use of volume name for lookup in the backend. First of all, Cinder has a volume name template option, which by default is 'volume-'. With the default for Zadara being 'OS_', you'll get names like OS_volume-UUID. With volume template name in general, I fear the cases where you have multiple Cinder services running with out of sync config settings for volume_name_template. I generally feel like just UUID is enough, but I may not really understand the use case well for the prefixes."}, {'account_id': 736, 'date': '2013-08-19 23:41:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (4 inline comments)

Mike,

Please see my answers to your comments below. For tests - i can remove unused vars if it is critical, but I would prefer to have them there (or we can comment them).

Re deprecated config params - this is completely fine to remove them.

and, finally, regarding generation of the OS name - it looks pretty good in our system and I would prefer to have a reference to the OpenStack in the name and not only the UUID. We were working with it like that in the past and I see no reason to change it on this stage.

I will really appreciate if you will revert your -1 to +1 :-)
I will be out till 8/29. If it is absolutely critical, I will ask one of my guys to remove these unused vars from the unit tests.

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-27 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-08-27 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Add features to Zadara Storage Cinder driver

- move to Zadara APIs 13.07
- added support for extend volume
- added support for create/delete snapshot
- added support for create clones from volumes and snaps
- added support for multi-backend
- added volume stats
- added tests

Implements: blueprint zadara-cinder-driver-update

Change-Id: Iad5908a50980c59df2d8d4702743a0b99f82f9b7

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-03 16:33:47.000000000', 'message': 'Set vg_thin_pool to pool name instead of pool_path

create_thin_pool is setting vg_thin_pool to the pool path instead of the
pool_name. This makes volumes creation fail when the create_thin_pool
method is called. This happens because create_volume builds the pool
path itself as create_thin_pool does.

Keeping the pool name in vg_thin_pool instead of the path makes more
sense and allows it to be used in other places in the brick. Also, most
commands return both vg_name and pool_name separated.

Change-Id: Ibf5cd746fc050eab5ce6aff13dd70c1e8066b228
Closes-Bug: #1220286
'}]
commit_message:
Set vg_thin_pool to pool name instead of pool_path

create_thin_pool is setting vg_thin_pool to the pool path instead of the
pool_name. This makes volumes creation fail when the create_thin_pool
method is called. This happens because create_volume builds the pool
path itself as create_thin_pool does.

Keeping the pool name in vg_thin_pool instead of the path makes more
sense and allows it to be used in other places in the brick. Also, most
commands return both vg_name and pool_name separated.

Change-Id: Ibf5cd746fc050eab5ce6aff13dd70c1e8066b228
Closes-Bug: #1220286

commit_message:
Refactoring for nicira plugin to support NVP DHCP/Metadata services

This initial patch is aimed at decoupling core plugin services from
DHCP and metadata services. The abstraction being introduced is
needed so that the code can support both models where dhcp and
metadata services are provided by external RPC agents or solely by
the server-side plugin.

Supports blueprint nvp-dhcp-metadata-services

Change-Id: I396ee7bbcbd866e4e9d4a79887e844b4f5ec3c9e

commit_message:
Guest-assisted-snaps libvirt implementation

This implements volume_snapshot_create and volume_snapshot_delete
methods which create snapshots of QCOW2-based Cinder volumes.

The update_snapshot_status API from cinderclient is used to
inform Cinder of the result of these operations.

This feature requires a minimum libvirt version of 1.1.1 due
to a bug in libvirt BlockJobInfo handling in earlier versions.

Libvirt implementation for blueprint qemu-assisted-snapshots

Change-Id: I76eb2e4da027a13525314bd58264f482374d270d

commit_message:
Default to not capturing log output in tests

Viewing log output while tests are still running can be useful for
debugging, but log output was previously always captured.  This
change ensures that log capture is off by default, but can still
be enabled by setting OS_LOG_CAPTURE=1 in the shell environment.

testr invocation is unchanged and will continue to capture logs by
default.

Change-Id: I9d0fb648541280cacfebb47f67f608378ae66ef3

Thank you for your adding common loading function for service drivers.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-08-14 01:20:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I've got a few high concerns with patch.
1) I don't like the separate call to associate _provider.  Feels like the provider attribute should be updated by changing the attribute on the pool.
2) Falling back to a no-op driver will actually hide misconfigurations.  When a driver is not available, the API commands should fail vs silently passing."}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-08-14 04:50:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

This was discussed during review of service type framework:
We need to handle a case when admin decides to remove provider from the configuration. (Not a misconfiguration, actually!)
 Removing provider must not result in loosing logical configurations, because users want to continue using the service with other provider.
That results in two requirements:
 1. Users should be able to operate on objects without provider
That's the reason to use no-op driver
 2. Users should be able to associate pools that has lost provider with another provider.
There is no method to disassociate or update provider, so it addresses only specific case of deleting providers."}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-08-14 12:34:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-08-14 17:08:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

BTW, rebase looks needed'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-08-14 18:28:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-14 19:27:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17: Doesn't seem to work

I have a few comments inline.

The only thing I am curious about if how you are trying to deal with existing service instances.
One strategy would be to automatically assign them with the default service provider; another would be to putting them down with the noop driver and the let the user redeploy them. It looks like you're going for the 2nd, is that right?"}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-08-16 14:06:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17: (7 inline comments)

Thanks for review Salvatore! Answering some of your comments.

'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-09-01 23:44:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm not sure where this paradigm started to sneak into our code, but a no-op driver is not a good idea.  No-ops increase the likelihood of  misconfiguration and do not provide any benefit because they're inherently ambiguous.   The provider should either be locked when the pool is created or changed via the update_pool.  This functionality should be available to both the tenant and admin (so we will not need separate rest endpoints updating).  In the event a deployer retires a provider, it is the deployers responsibility to manage the transition."}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-09-02 22:19:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 31.'}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-09-02 22:34:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 32.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-02 22:57:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32: Works for me

* adds support for multiple plugin drivers for loadbalancer
* cleans up healthmonitor-related plugin driver API
Drivers should work with healthmonitor associations only

The patch makes the following changes:

* adds new attribute of the pool: provider, which is provider name
as it is written in configuration
* adds support for multiple plugin drivers for loadbalancer
* cleans up healthmonitor-related plugin driver API

were removed from configuration

to reassociate pools with new providers in case their providers
were removed from configuration

implements blueprint lbaas-integration-with-service-types

DocImpact

Change-Id: I4295c9bcceb38e60f813d5596af48bd8194c1c9b
'}]
commit_message:
LBaaS integration with service type framework

The patch makes the following changes:

* adds new attribute of the pool: provider, which is provider name
as it is written in configuration
* adds support for multiple plugin drivers for loadbalancer
* cleans up healthmonitor-related plugin driver API
Drivers should work with healthmonitor associations only
* adds ability to update provider attribute for the pool used
to reassociate pools with new providers in case their providers
were removed from configuration

implements blueprint lbaas-integration-with-service-types

DocImpact

Change-Id: I4295c9bcceb38e60f813d5596af48bd8194c1c9b

commit_message:
get quota set for an invalid tenant ID return default quota set

when use an invalid tenant ID to show  quota, you should get a error message, rather than default quota set.

Fixs Bug #1215320

Change-Id: I6ce8afae02e61321b1842ea597913e05296ec0f0

commit_message:
Check whether the security group id is integer or UUID

Nova and Neutron provide the security group, respectively.
nova's security group id is integer, and neutron's is UUID.

Fixes Bug 1217242

Change-Id: I7d9f43837860f08b9f5e841ceffa7f823807e9a4

revisions:

A Trove Instance that is created and booted successfully has a service_statuses status as running.When the instance is deleted however, the service_statuses record remains unchanged. This fix updates the status to deleted.

commit_message:
Trove - service_statuses status set to delete when instance deleted

A Trove Instance that is created and booted successfully has a
service_statuses status as running.When the instance is deleted
however, the service_statuses record remains unchanged.
This fix updates the status to deleted.

Change-Id: Ied0b740e2de563f6337dbbcc3c026aad2777cc53
Fixes: bug #1200373

commit_message:
Turning nfs default options into attributes

forgot to include these two defaults as attributes in the initial
nfs support submission.

This change allows the user to tweak nfs_disk_util and nfs_sparsed_volumes

Change-Id: Ic4f03d1059b75789d465bbb7db71aa89ea61b94d

One other reason I would say we might want to keep this separate from the old volume extension is because the assisted snapshots should be an internal-only admin API that should only be consumed by Cinder and never hit by users. 

This is of course possible to enforce in this state of the patch but seems like needlessly hiding the fact that it's admin only (although I could be cool with that since it goes away in v3). commit_message:
Add os-assisted-volume-snapshots extension

Add a new API extension that exposes assisted volume snapshot
capabilities.  This extension is admin only by default.  We expect it to
only be called by Cinder.  If you have your deployment set up in such a
way that your adminURL is different from the public, this extension can
only be loaded in the admin API instance.  Cinder will pull that URL out
of the service catalog to use.

Part of blueprint qemu-assisted-snapshots

Change-Id: I79e22ab6ef66fa16dc534a4336e766065702b2f5

commit_message:
VMware: remove conditional suds validation

suds is now part of the requirements.txt file so we no longer
need the conditional check.

Fixes bug 1220344

subject: Use separate disqus sites
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-03 06:15:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-openstack-manuals-validate http://logs.openstack.org/00/44800/1/check/gate-openstack-manuals-validate/fe52c5d : SUCCESS in 9s
'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2013-09-03 09:51:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Does that mean we are loosing old comments ?'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2013-09-03 12:44:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Emilien, good question. Looking at disqus.com, I see no way to migrate this - and thus assume we should not do this for old branches. Anne, can you confirm?'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2013-09-03 20:35:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I prefer to let Anne approve this patch.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2013-09-03 21:44:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

So, when going to a new disqus ID from one that was used for multiple guides, we won't migrate. If there's a one-to-one match, I have migrated comment threads successfully in the past. I'm fine with that trade-off but it's a very good question, thanks Emilien. 

I do believe that readers can still see the comments on the disqus.com site itself, if that's useful. But the threads will no longer be on the page they were before."}, {'account_id': 1177, 'date': '2013-09-03 22:18:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2013-09-03 22:26:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-03 22:26:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-03 22:26:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build succeeded.

- gate-openstack-manuals-validate http://logs.openstack.org/00/44800/1/gate/gate-openstack-manuals-validate/2725c5b : SUCCESS in 6s
'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-03 22:26:35.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Action engine: save task results

Task results are saved on success and passed to revert method
on revert. If task failed (execute method raised an exception),
special object of type taskflow.utils.misc.Failure is created
and saved as task result to indicate that.

To store results Storage class is introduced. As for now it is
simple tiny wrapper of a dictionary, but future plans include
rewriting it using persistence API and adding more sophisticated
functionality.

Change-Id: Ic806421a3780653602d8879c33fdf655950a6804

commit_message:
Initial implementation of action-based engine

This is first in series of changes that provides separation of flows into
engines and pattens. Patterns define structure, while engine define how
the task should be run according to said structure.

This change adds the basic patterns and a very simple engine that
is able to run flow defined with patterns by converting it to recursive
structure of so-called 'actions'.

For simplicity and ease of review certain major features like
resumption, saving and passing on task results and notifications are
left out for farther changes.

Partially implements blueprint patterns-and-engines

Co-authored-by: Anastasia Karpinska <akarpinska at griddynamics.com>
Change-Id: I68515d8a5b30d5d047bf9beb67cc3e2111175190

commit_message:
Allowing to pass network name to router gateway

This patch allows to pass newtork name instead of network id to create router
gateway. It is really useful feature because often router has gateway as public
network. It is easy to pass the name because id will change after deleting the
network and creating it again.

Change-Id: I5768408b86b509ecfd117f17b10db06af82369d8

commit_message:
Custom CA certificate for verifying SSL connections

The various OpenStack client libaries support specifying a SSL
certificate that should be used to verify the SSL-connection, but
this option was not exposed in the horizon options. This patch
implements that. Note that although some clients do implement a
cacert-parameter, they do not necessarily actually verify the
certificate (Swift).

Change-Id: I9dfbd48a0d96103421da7d884e839d591a90cab1
Implements: blueprint ssl-cacert

@Oleg: The unit testing for this change set should be covered by the unit testing that will be added as part of blueprint "ml2-md-cisco-nexus". Some background: The change set that you're reviewing here was originally part of the change set for Cisco mech driver blueprint. Without these changes to manager.py, Cisco mech driver unit tests were failing because of the static nature of the driver dictionaries/lists. So when the Cisco mech driver changes (with unit test code) are committed (after this bug is committed), we will have a test that changes to ML2 drivers are permitted when ML2 type and mechanism manager objects are instantiated. Another part of this change set was the removal of a test for redundant names in the mechanism driver list... this test is not required because it's not possible to have redundant names in this namespace (please see comments from Bob K. for patch set 2).'}, {'account_id': 6695, 'date': '2013-09-03 20:13:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-09-03 20:13:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-03 17:44:09.000000000', 'message': "Fixes bug 1220296

The ML2 plugin's type and mechanism managers currently maintain dictionaries/lists of type drivers, mechanism drivers, and ordered mechanism drivers in (static) class variables. Once a type/mechanism/ordered-mechanism driver of any given type is added to this list, then no new drivers of that type are allowed to be registered, and therefore no new configuration for that driver type is accepted.

This static nature of the driver dictionaries/lists is causing ML2 mechanism driver unit test cases to fail. For example, if a non-vendor-specific ML2 plugin test case configures a VLAN type driver with no VLAN range, and then a vendor specific test case attempts to configure a VLAN type driver with some test VLAN range, then the new VLAN configuration is ignored because of the previously (staticly) registered VLAN driver.

The proposed fix is to convert these driver dictionaries/lists to instance variables, and clear them upon each instantiation of an ML2 type manager or ML2 mechanism manager.

Change-Id: I3b5209640de229899561e2a3ec7c6dafe9a05e64

driver of any given type is added to this list, then no new drivers of that
type are allowed to be registered, and therefore no new configuration for
that driver type is accepted.

This static nature of the driver dictionaries/lists is causing ML2 mechanism
driver unit test cases to fail. For example, if a non-vendor-specific ML2
plugin test case configures a VLAN type driver with no VLAN range, and then
a vendor specific test case attempts to configure a VLAN type driver with
some test VLAN range, then the new VLAN configuration is ignored because of
the previously (staticly) registered VLAN driver.

The proposed fix is to convert these driver dictionaries/lists to instance
variables, and clear them upon each instantiation of an ML2 type manager
or ML2 mechanism manager.

Change-Id: I3b5209640de229899561e2a3ec7c6dafe9a05e64
"}, {'created': '2013-09-03 20:31:14.000000000', 'message': "ML2 type and mech managers should use instance vars for drivers lists

Fixes bug 1220296

The ML2 plugin's type and mechanism managers currently maintain

drivers in (static) class variables. Once a type/mechanism/ordered-mechanism

type are allowed to be registered, and therefore no new configuration for
that driver type is accepted.

This static nature of the driver dictionaries/lists is causing ML2 mechanism
driver unit test cases to fail. For example, if a non-vendor-specific ML2
plugin test case configures a VLAN type driver with no VLAN range, and then
a vendor specific test case attempts to configure a VLAN type driver with
some test VLAN range, then the new VLAN configuration is ignored because of
the previously (staticly) registered VLAN driver.

The proposed fix is to convert these driver dictionaries/lists to instance
variables, and clear them upon each instantiation of an ML2 type manager
or ML2 mechanism manager.

Change-Id: I3b5209640de229899561e2a3ec7c6dafe9a05e64
"}]
commit_message:
ML2 type and mech managers should use instance vars for drivers lists

Fixes bug 1220296

The ML2 plugin's type and mechanism managers currently maintain
dictionaries/lists of type drivers, mechanism drivers, and ordered mechanism
drivers in (static) class variables. Once a type/mechanism/ordered-mechanism
driver of any given type is added to this list, then no new drivers of that
type are allowed to be registered, and therefore no new configuration for
that driver type is accepted.

This static nature of the driver dictionaries/lists is causing ML2 mechanism
driver unit test cases to fail. For example, if a non-vendor-specific ML2
plugin test case configures a VLAN type driver with no VLAN range, and then
a vendor specific test case attempts to configure a VLAN type driver with
some test VLAN range, then the new VLAN configuration is ignored because of
the previously (staticly) registered VLAN driver.

The proposed fix is to convert these driver dictionaries/lists to instance
variables, and clear them upon each instantiation of an ML2 type manager
or ML2 mechanism manager.

Change-Id: I3b5209640de229899561e2a3ec7c6dafe9a05e64

[{'created': '2013-09-02 14:09:20.000000000', 'message': "Don't use a query for watch_rule_get()

When getting a database record by ID, it is much more efficient to get() it
directly than to perform a query or the database to obtain the ID (again)
and then get it.

Change-Id: I89b46d698c033e54ee9a50172ccad3eb3833cb1e
"}]
commit_message:
Don't use a query for watch_rule_get()

When getting a database record by ID, it is much more efficient to get() it
directly than to perform a query or the database to obtain the ID (again)
and then get it.

Change-Id: I89b46d698c033e54ee9a50172ccad3eb3833cb1e
