(3 inline comments)

A couple in-line comments, plus:

* I apologize for bringing this up so late in the review process, and maybe its already been discussed, but I'm wondering what the justification is for maintaining driver-specific database tables that are mostly redundant copies of data already stored in existing ml2 or core tables? Is this being done solely to support the synchronization with EOS? Has the possibility of using the existing DB access classes, querying the existing DB models, or maybe extending ml2 with a general mechanism for enumerating resources been considered? If something like this makes sense but isn't reasonable for Havana, I'm OK with addressing this later.

* How about a README file with an overview of the driver, a list of the hardware it supports, and maybe a link to a Wiki page with more info?

* Does this driver assume only a single physical network is being used? If not, the physical_network needs to be used along with segmentation_id. If so, please make that very clear in the README.

* Assuming ml2-portbindings and ml2-multi-segment-api implementations get merged for Havana, it seems this driver's current DB models will need some adjustment to allow for different ports on the same network to bind using different segments."}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-08-27 21:30:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 6558, 'date': '2013-08-28 21:23:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 6558, 'date': '2013-08-28 21:34:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (4 inline comments)

Hi Bob, 

Thanks for taking time to review this Patch. I reviewed your comments and thought I give you some back ground about the roadmap and plan for the driver. 

- Initial version of the driver only supports single segment and single physical network - i.e. VLANs. We were not sure if multi-segment support was going to make it in havana time frame. So, we decided to go with single segment version first. 
- As to your comment on the DB. The only reason I save DB is for the Neutron/EOS sync. I looked around the DBs available in ML2 as well core. While all the information is available, it is scattered all around and the ability to filter the information by. Since the intent is to implement bulk sync down the road (where we will not be sending one network information, but N networks at a time), I felt if I organized the data where it is most efficient to perform the sync, that was the motivation to organize the Db this way. Having said that, I do not dispute the fact that I can eliminate some of the fields from these tables. 
- Per your suggestion, I have created a README file as well as wiki. README file is included in this submission which includes a link to the wiki.
- I have created a bug to track the port-binding integration. As a part of this bug, if there is a need to make any change to the DB, I will do that.  https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1215097

Hope this addresses all your comments. 

Thanks
-Sukhdev'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-28 22:50:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Doesn't seem to work

Rich, I think we decided to go with both models. I am cutting and pasting from the meeting notes as to what we decided. Looks like for Cisco, you need ml2/drivers/cisco/ and put your multiple drivers in there.

 <mestery> So, to summarize: Single file mech drivers are in drivers/mech_*.py. Single mech drivers with multiple files are in drivers/mech_*/. commit_message:
Arista ML2 Mechanism driver

This patch implements Arista's modular L2 mechanism driver to
automate the management of virtual networks along with physical networks
using Arista hardware devices (Spine and Leaf switches)

This driver uses ML2 Mechanism Driver-API to interface with Neutron ML2 Plugin.

implements: blueprint arista-ml2-mechanism-driver

Change-Id: I1c4ca36cf3d7af013b7b3353e7b7d89fe39f91bf

commit_message:
add 'project' notifications to docs

In addition to adding a mention about 'project' notifications, I rewrote
a few bits of the notifications docs to make it easier to add new
resource types as we implement them (you only have to add them to the
list, rather than revising a bunch of disparate paragraphs).

blueprint notifications

Change-Id: I4792e5dd368d5404c252d6c7c8dc8813af7509d8

commit_message:
Add Aggregate object model

This adds an Aggregate object model implementation.

Related to blueprint compute-api-objects

Change-Id: Ic947718766181f8262fcf171b2bc0c329e0ae8f9

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-02 04:46:18.000000000', 'message': 'Further updates to update.py

1. Adjust how import reforming is done to use a function
   to reform the import line (after modification).
2. Clean the old copy of taskflow (if it exists) before
   placing a new copy in its place, this is very useful
   to avoid stale files.
3. Move some constants to be offical global constants.
4. Show exactly what modules are being used from the
   containing projects openstack.common.
5. Fix how the distributed flow was breaking imports due
   to the location/usage of logbook in that module no
   longer being functionally correct.

commit_message:
Further updates to update.py

1. Adjust how import reforming is done to use a function
   to reform the import line (after modification).
2. Clean the old copy of taskflow (if it exists) before
   placing a new copy in its place, this is very useful
   to avoid stale files.
3. Move some constants to be offical global constants.
4. Show exactly what modules are being used from the
   containing projects openstack.common.
5. Fix how the distributed flow was breaking imports due
   to the location/usage of logbook in that module no
   longer being functionally correct.
6. Add a header to each file copied/created that tells
   people not to modify them directly.

Gary, if we want a variant that allows integers or, say, JSON-able types, then that's fine. commit_message:
Add dict and list utility functions for object typing

This adds list_of_strings_or_none() and dict_of_strings_or_none()
to objects.utils. This makes it easy to enforce things like
metadata chunks and lists of hostnames.

Related to blueprint compute-api-objects

Change-Id: Iecd40c12da81f4f69312182d619cc12d071137a1

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-03 07:46:38.000000000', 'message': 'Split utils module

In this commit we split utils module into several parts:
- flow_utils, with code used in running flows;
- threading_utils, with code that helps in working with threads;
- reflection, with code that inspects python objects metadata;
- misc, with all the other code that used to live in utils.py.

We also move graph_utils into taskflow.utils package.

This commit just moves code around. It should not change any logic (with
exception of complex_graph example).

Change-Id: Iebfe45395f0ff502bc00fc7ae14829130b2c6abe
'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-03 04:08:38.000000000', 'message': "Change from using 'cypher_type' to 'mode' in API and code base.

The term 'mode' is better aligned with the cypher community than
'cypher_type' is. Therefore, it would be less confusing to change
the name of this attribute prior to the M3 feature freeze.

Change-Id: Ibf99bd730e9a3ff7bd1f49f4252cc860a60e9295
"}]
commit_message:
Change from using 'cypher_type' to 'mode' in API and code base.

The term 'mode' is better aligned with the cypher community than
'cypher_type' is. Therefore, it would be less confusing to change
the name of this attribute prior to the M3 feature freeze.

Change-Id: Ibf99bd730e9a3ff7bd1f49f4252cc860a60e9295

commit_message:
Remove duplicate TenantSecret on secret PUT call.

During a two step Secret creation (so a POST followed by a PUT) a duplicate TenantSecret
record is created.  This commit is to remove this duplicate record.

Change-Id: If877f6fb45de1b772bdbdeac4f757e8269cb04f3
Implements: blueprint datamodel-remove-dup-tenantsecret-on-put

commit_message:
Implement resize volume method

Trove use Cinder as volume backend default and Cinder requires that volume must
in "available" status if wish to resize. So we should stop db firstly, then
detach volume from instance and resize volume. Finally, restart db in ease.

If resize volume failed, the instance may stuck into "RESIZE" status. Because
we have no idea to rescue the volume which is in "error_extending" by Cinder.

implement bp implement-volume-extend

Change-Id: Iff3b302a705917e0e27cd70edf6e1be1639f62d5

Wow... a change between single-quoted strings and double-quoted strings in the XML declaration managed to break a client? That's... impressive.

I mean, I can sort of see a brittle, hand-rolled timestamp parser breaking because it doesn't expect a timezone character after the year, but the quote type? I looked at the source of the library and there appears to be no way short of writing a complete method or patching the "xml" method with our own serializer.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-08-31 05:34:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm having trouble coming down on this one, I think it would help quite a bit actually if you were able to specifically name the client.

Here's how we got here:

Add the Z
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/38008/

^ this fixed a real bug where we were returning an invalid response, right?https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1169287/comments/4
Can we at least keep the fix in the json?  Do we reopen the bug and then mark it invalid?

Change the quotes
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/38681/

^ the quotes is the one that throws me the most... was that a problem?  really?
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6800467/quotes-in-xml-single-or-double
What about the charset stuff... *that* stuff was all fine?!

If we're gunna take the hard line stance; I feel like it'd almost be easier for me to swallow if we just revert those commits out right?

If we are willing to accept this is a fine line, knowing the specifics of the old client would make all the difference:  I could understand the failure behavior, if there's a work-around, the state, age and availability of the effected project, if these changes work with a newer versions, what versions ship with which distributions, releases and platforms, how obviously wrong is the parser, do they have problems with other API's, if they would accept a patch, etc.

Knowing all/some of that, I could *totally* see my self coming down on the side of !REVERT! 1REVERT!

But as it stands this just doesn't feel very pragmatic to me.  OTOH, I don't *currently* have any clients bending my ear about changing the format of these responses.  :D

If others are sure they know the right thing to do here, please don't let me hold up the show - I'm obviously torn."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-08-31 06:48:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I wouldn't equate using a non-standard date format with "sending an invalid response".  We never documented it as being an ISO-8601 date.  It'd be better if it was, but it's kind of late in the API to change the contract.'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-09-03 14:13:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Certain old clients that shall not be named do not like some of the
recent changes to the xml output for container listings.  This fixes
those changes.  If we want to change any of the xml output, then we
should do it in another API version.  I'm not sure if any of these

DocImpact

Change-Id: I983332ca9d620a9a539be26bc6655df9b2ef87ed

commit_message:
Fix changes in XML that broke old clients

Certain old clients that shall not be named do not like some of the
recent changes to the xml output for container listings.  This fixes
those changes.  If we want to change any of the xml output, then we
should do it in another API version.  I'm not sure if any of these
changes in the XML were put in any documentation, but if they were, they
should be changed back.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I983332ca9d620a9a539be26bc6655df9b2ef87ed

commit_message:
Fix deprecated params user_id, role_id, tenant_id

Update keystone cli by changing parameter options (user_id, role_id and tenant_id)
to use '-' rather than '_' in the method user_role_add and consequently the method
user_role_remove without maintain backward compatibility because these are deprecated.

python-keystoneclient - Bug #1150434
Change-Id: Ia5113718eb050cf7dba443b8d0caf3bdaa1730f0

commit_message:
Remove EC2 postfix from InvalidInstanceIDMalformedEC2

With new EC2 error code handling based on ec2_code attribute,
there is no justification for the EC2 postfix.

Implements: blueprint ec2-error-codes

Change-Id: I97ede9a3bcba3a6ac48de50fb6f451f8357a4848

subject: Introduce InternalError EC2 error code

commit_message:
Introduce InternalError EC2 error code

New InternalError exception with 'InternalError' ec2_code attribute was
introduced for the case of timeout when waiting for instance to stop
because there is no fitting existing exception.

InternalError is a valid EC2 error code. Unlike the other implemented
error codes, it's a server error with 500 status code. For that reason,
it's not listed as an expected error in the Executor and thus it's
treated as an unexpected error - it's logged as ERROR and returned
with 500 status code. That is a wanted behaviur because this shouldn't
ever happen and if it does, it should be visible.

Implements: blueprint ec2-error-codes

Change-Id: I11d25abfe46f5b3acdecb4fa2d31f4cec054cba1

commit_message:
Implements bp: volume_retype

Add the ability to modify change the type of an
existing volume to another type.

The new type must be supported by the backend that the
volume currently resides on and is verified by the filter
scheduler (same methods as used for create with specified type).

***WIP***
Needs:
  Unit tests
  Fix quotas

Change-Id: I5f5210153109b4b6a2be0fdd8a0e18bf23eff8f2

Can you link tos some docs on why UnsupportedOperation is valid for all of these cases (for example FloatinIpAssociated could be Resource.AlreadyAssociated). I checked the blueprint docs and couldn't find anything."}, {'account_id': 6717, 'date': '2013-08-28 13:30:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I can't because there is no such thing. Only docs about this I'm aware of are http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/api-error-codes.html which only have brief descriptions of errors. To mimic the API, reproducing the errors in Amazon EC2 and checking the response would be required.

I believe all these cases are OpenStack specific, so there is no clear mapping to EC2 error codes because EC2 simply doesn't encounter these problems at all.

I've arbitrarily chosen UnsupportedOperation for all OpenStack specific occasions for now but it could be Resource.AlreadyAssociated here and ResourceLimitExceeded there. Or we could use our own error code since these errors are OpenStack specific and thus incompatible by nature.

As of Resource.AlreadyAssociated specifically, it says "The specified gateway is already attached, or specified subnet is already associated with another object." which isn't exactly fitting FloatingIpAssociated, or is it?'}, {'account_id': 6717, 'date': '2013-08-28 15:18:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2013-08-28 15:20:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
Introduce UnsupportedOperation EC2 error code

'UnsupportedOperation' ec2_code attribute was added to following
exceptions that are OpenStack specific and don't have mapping to EC2
error codes because EC2 simply doesn't encounter these problems at all.

 * CannotDisassociateAutoAssignedFloatingIP
 * FloatingIpAssociated
 * FloatingIpNotFound
 * NoFloatingIpInterface
 * NoMoreFixedIps
 * InvalidVolume

Catch these direcly in Executor instead of translating them to useless
EC2APIError. This way, user will also get meaningful error messages.

Implements: blueprint ec2-error-codes

Change-Id: I62ea97658cee85e5285f55cba600a08d01fe7cdd

commit_message:
Introduce SecurityGroupLimitExceeded EC2 error code

SecurityGroupLimitExceeded is a valid EC2 error code. Add it as an ec2_code
attribute to the exception of same name and use it where appropriate
instead of useless EC2APIError.

Implements: blueprint ec2-error-codes

Change-Id: I1558b9f69c912dab9d829aacd5c5aae1c37f12b9

subject: Introduce IncorrectState EC2 error code

New IncorrectStateEC2 exception is raised instead of useless EC2APIError.

Although IncorrectState EC2 error code is used for volumes only in
Amazon EC2, it's used for incorrect image state in nova as well
because there is no error code for this (EC2 images are stateless)
and inventing new error code is a bad idea.

Implements: blueprint ec2-error-codes
Change-Id: I3566bbc4b2eb13482c93933932dd619f90cbc234

commit_message:
Introduce IncorrectState EC2 error code

'IncorrectState' ec2_code attribute was added to ImageNotActive and
VolumeUnattached exceptions.

ImageNotActive is now used instead of useless EC2APIError.

Although IncorrectState EC2 error code is used for volumes only in
Amazon EC2, it's used for incorrect image state in nova as well
because there is no error code for this (EC2 images are stateless)
and inventing new error code is a bad idea.

Implements: blueprint ec2-error-codes

Change-Id: I3566bbc4b2eb13482c93933932dd619f90cbc234

commit_message:
Introduce AuthFailure EC2 error code

AuthFailure is a valid EC2 error code, use it where appropriate.

Add 'AuthFailure' ec2_code attribute to NotAuthorized exception.

Return AuthFailure during Keystone authentication errors and add unit
tests to cover this. When Keystone returns HTTP error code, use
the same code for EC2 error response.

Implements: blueprint ec2-error-codes

Change-Id: I17306d9a5364e095e787dbf0dbb5b88a899372e3

'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-08-30 14:46:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

cool'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-09-02 11:39:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Please see the inline question. I think that the treatment here may be a little too brad and there are 2 edge cases:
1. the snapshot was actually not done - and due to exception handling we will try and delete an image that does not exists on glance
2. the snapshot was successfully done and due to an exception we will delete a image that is perfectly ok.
Maybe the exception handling you have added should be more specific and just around the actual snapshot handling and posting to glance"}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-09-02 12:02:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (1 inline comment)

The glance image for the snapshot is created before the compute manager is called, in the compute api.

If something bad happens, like a network error when uploading the image to glance, or glance runs out of space, or whatever, then we want to catch that.

I would wrap the exception around just the driver call, but I wanted to cover cases where the instance is deleted before updating the status in the DB, and you get an exception due to a miss-match in the db state, for example.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-09-03 18:59:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
On snapshot errors delete the image

The snapshot, backup and live-backup method create images in glance that
are then uploaded to. Should an issue occur during the image upload, we
should remove that glance image.

Fixes bug 1200804
Change-Id: Ib9b84c6721932c5184cf283b47f74ca57bfb83ce

[{'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-07-18 09:35:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Luke,

 1) The code you have posted is far from the style described in HACKING.rst. Please follow the guide.
 2) Commit message should describe the code being committed. It's not a place for questions and discussions.
 3) Please add unit tests for your code.
 4) Please mark patch as 'Work In Progress'"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-18 09:48:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/37647/1/check/gate-neutron-pep8/647 : FAILURE in 2m 05s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/37647/1/check/gate-neutron-docs/647/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 48s
- http://logs.openstack.org/37647/1/check/gate-neutron-python26/644 : SUCCESS in 20m 59s
- http://logs.openstack.org/37647/1/check/gate-neutron-python27/646 : SUCCESS in 15m 09s
- http://logs.openstack.org/37647/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron/5136 : SUCCESS in 17m 19s (non-voting)
"}, {'account_id': 7712, 'date': '2013-07-18 18:45:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Hey Luke,

Answering your last question quickly - you need to register your mechanism driver setup.cfg. This assigns the name to your mechanism driver that you then put into the mechanism_driver list in your ml2 config.

On the question of pushing deltas - you know the key of what has changed in the calls to (create|update|delete)_RESOURCE, so can't you just use that to sync that one entry of that one table?

On the question of tables_to_sync and how much to synchronize - that's really up to your use case and what you're going to do with the data. The main thing I would worry about is how your solution scales when the various tables you're synchronizing get large.

Andre"}, {'account_id': 6558, 'date': '2013-07-20 04:16:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Will you not have scale issue with this implementation? 

Why not send one record at a time when the create_xx() operation is invoked and have a separate thread to do periodic synchronization to make sure Neutron and your back-end are in sync - just a thought.'}, {'account_id': 7916, 'date': '2013-07-26 09:37:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7916, 'date': '2013-07-26 09:43:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks very much for the great feedback.

I have uploaded a much revised version and I would love some feedback on the validity of the design, particularly - is it okay to use get_network()/get_port() as I do for reading the state that I want to replicate?

I still have work to do on PEP8 compliance and unit tests.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-26 10:00:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/47/37647/2/check/gate-neutron-pep8/981 : FAILURE in 2m 27s

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-18 09:27:18.000000000', 'message': '"Embarrassingly simple" first version of Tailf-NCS integration.

The goal of this commit is to show my intention and solicit feedback
using an admittedly over-simplified plugin implementation.

High-level intention:
1. Replicate certain Neutron database tables to NCS using HTTP/JSON.
2. In case NCS rejects the changes then cause a rollback in Neutron.

Specific design issues that I would love feedback on:

1. I am talking directly to the database to access the records that I
   want to replicate, rather than using e.g. mechanism API context
   objects. Is this reasonable? (I may want to sync more information
   than just these tables -- do we want the mechansim driver API to
   scale up to this use case?)

2. Recommendation for how to push deltas instead of the whole DB in
   the usual case of single configuration changes?

3. How about 'tables_to_sync' contents? do other people also want to
   synchronize a lot of Neutron state to external systems? or is there
   some good reason to synchronize less? (I am mostly motivated by
   future-proofing.)

also the small practical matter:

How do I load and run this mechanism driver? (I have actually tested it by overwriting mechanism_test.py, it's a mystery to me how Stevedore manages to find that.)

Thanks!

Change-Id: I1f73fa3f2e4eec8e5a0f2865aec2d934e25c76d1

commit_message:
ML2 Mechanism Driver for Tail-f Network Control System (NCS)

Define a new ML2 Mechanism Driver that replicates Neutron network/port
configuration changes to NCS: http://www.tail-f.com/network-control-system/

Configuration is sent using a HTTP/JSON interface.

Implements blueprint tailf-ncs

Change-Id: I1f73fa3f2e4eec8e5a0f2865aec2d934e25c76d1

subject: xenapi: add support for auto_disk_config=disabled

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-25 11:04:59.000000000', 'message': "Add support for auto_disk_config=disabled

Previously, only True and False where supported. This change allows an
administrator to specify which images should reject any user requests
for DiskConfig=AUTO, i.e. reject the request to automatically resize
that instance's root disk.

Implements blueprint auto-disk-config-disabled

Change-Id: Ifd41886b9bc7dff01cdf741a833946bed1bdddc3
"}, {'created': '2013-07-25 14:49:08.000000000', 'message': "Add support for auto_disk_config=disabled

Previously, only True and False where supported. This change allows an
administrator to specify which images should reject any user requests
for DiskConfig=AUTO, i.e. reject the request to automatically resize
that instance's root disk.

In addition, when uploading a snapshot we use the image property when
propagating auto_config_disk, rather than using the boolean that is
persisted directly in the instance record.

TODO - need to check other calls, like resize.

Implements blueprint auto-disk-config-disabled

Change-Id: Ifd41886b9bc7dff01cdf741a833946bed1bdddc3

Change-Id: Ifd41886b9bc7dff01cdf741a833946bed1bdddc3
"}, {'created': '2013-07-31 16:37:09.000000000', 'message': "xenapi: add support for auto_disk_config=disabled

Previously, only True and False where supported. This change allows an
administrator to specify which images should reject any user requests
for DiskConfig=AUTO, i.e. reject the request to automatically resize
that instance's root disk.

auto_disk_config is disabled, that property is inherited by any

commit_message:
xenapi: add support for auto_disk_config=disabled

Previously, only True and False were supported. This change allows an
administrator to specify which images should reject any user requests
for DiskConfig=AUTO, i.e. reject the request to automatically resize
that instance's root disk.

To specify that an image's disk can't be resized, add the following
property to the image:
auto_disk_config=disabled

In addition, when uploading a snapshot we need to ensure that if
auto_disk_config is "disabled", that property is inherited by any
snapshot. Currently, the disk_config from the database, which is always
False in the case of "disabled", would be persisted instead. When
auto_disk_config is not "disabled", then the current True or False value
for that server should continue to be persisted in any snapshot, and not
the value stored in the source image for that server.

DocImpact
Implements blueprint auto-disk-config-disabled
Change-Id: Ifd41886b9bc7dff01cdf741a833946bed1bdddc3

commit_message:
Implement basic caching around assignment CRUD

Implements caching around basic assignment CRUD actions.
    * assignment_api.get_domain
    * assignmnet_api.get_domain_by_name
    * assignment_api.get_project
    * assignment_api.get_project_by_name
    * assignment_api.get_role

The Create, Update, and Delete actions for domains, projects and
roles will perform proper invalidations of the cached methods listed
above.

Specific Cache Layer Tests added around assignment CRUD.

Modifications of LDAP tests done to handle caching concepts.

List methods are not covered by this patchset (list_projects, list_domains,
list_roles).

Grants are not subject to caching in this patchset.

DocImpact

partial-blueprint: caching-layer-for-driver-calls
Change-Id: Ic4e1a2d93078e55649ce9410ebece9b4d09b095a

commit_message:
Replace tearDown with NestedTempfile Fixture

Teardown isn't called if Setup errors, this should be more reliable.

Change-Id: I7804738527b1da18908652cf5dee591d75fa66b5

commit_message:
Add volume driver for Huawei HVS storage system

Huawei OceanStor HVS-series enterprise storage system is an optimum
storage platform for next-generation data centers that feature
virtualization, hybrid cloud, simplified IT, and low carbon footprints.

This patch add an iSCSI driver and a FC driver for Huawei HVS storage
system, using REST. We define a common module for both iSCSI driver and
FC driver. The drivers support volume type, QoS.

Implements: blueprint huawei-hvs-volume-driver
Change-Id: Ibdfed7df6d347e00f498694898c88dfa641559eb

commit_message:
Make ipsec_site_connection dpd_timeout == dpd_interval return 400

dpd_timeout == dpd_interval is a invalid case,
so in this commit, we modify validation and added test.
Fixes bug 1219440

Change-Id: I14fb9aa7df890f9c5a27f18f20d7dc1a316b2d79

Just a thought, does it make sense to add an not-so-explict API for guest-assisted-snapshots completion, which can be more flexible to handle not just metadata?  Like Avishay's doing for migrating attached volume: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/41285/18/cinder/api/contrib/admin_actions.py ?"}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-08-26 14:11:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(7 inline comments)

Something went wrong with my update here, a lot of this code was supposed to go away (to match the commit message).

@winston-d: I'm not sure I follow what you mean exactly.  The update API here only changes the 'status' and 'progress' fields of the snapshot.  Avishay's migrate volume API seems to do a similar update, but does it inside the volume manager rather than from higher in the API layer like the update operation here.  Is that a better way to do this?"}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-08-26 16:52:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: (7 inline comments)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-22 23:23:16.000000000', 'message': "GuestAssistedSnapshots

Initial implementation of APIs for Guest Assisted Snapshots.

Adds volume_action:
 - create_snapshot_metadata: Create a snapshot in 'creating' state
    but don't call driver snapshot code.
Adds snapshot_actions:
 - new module
 - finalize_snapshot_metadata: Finalize a snapshot created with
    create_snapshot_metadata action, resulting in 'available' or
    'error' state.
 - delete_snapshot_metadata: Delete a snapshot created with
    create_snapshot_metadata action, which removes the snapshot
    but does not call driver snapshot code.

TODO:
  tests

Implements blueprint qemu-assisted-snapshots

Change-Id: I54772f794b97e1cc6b24b121b757219248e37109

commit_message:
New update_snapshot_status API

Adds new snapshot_actions module

Update_snapshot_status: Allows updating of 'state' and
'progress' fields of a snapshot.  This is used by Nova
to inform Cinder of its outcome when performing snapshot
operations for attached volumes.  Updates are restricted
to a subset of possible start and finish states.

Implements blueprint qemu-assisted-snapshots

Change-Id: I54772f794b97e1cc6b24b121b757219248e37109

The setUpclass full chain detection realys on calling at leat
 one test_method, but this is not happening when the setUpClass

Change-Id: I679d328591b10c8f0a8f3cb66ba250cdff2ecf05

commit_message:
KeyError when tearDownClass called from setUpClass

The setUpclass full chain detection realys on calling at leat
 one test_method, but this is not happening when the setUpClass
failing.

Partially Fixing Bug: 1218279

Change-Id: I679d328591b10c8f0a8f3cb66ba250cdff2ecf05

commit_message:
Allow use of oslo.messaging 1.2.0a11

Since a11:

 1806c07 Remove check_for_lock support in RPCClient
 f7cf853 Don't include msg_id or reply_q in casts
 aebe53f Fix race-condition in rabbit reply processing
 59299dc Fix error message if message handler fails

Change-Id: Ic55d4214ff091456e33a028b584bab340c30eab0

[{'created': '2013-08-30 17:52:26.000000000', 'message': "Increase default test timeout for timeout fixture

This commit increases the default timeout for a test specified in
.testr.conf from 250 secs to 450 secs. The default build timeout
used for waiting for resource deletion is 400 secs. By using a test
timeout that was smaller than the build timeout some slow async
resource creation and deletions weren't completing before the test
was marked as failed for taking to long

Change-Id: Ia6292e68a8c3a0a0c03667a15f528c2ec6a5fbed
Partial-Bug: #1218585
"}, {'created': '2013-08-30 18:00:44.000000000', 'message': "Increase default test timeout for timeout fixture

This commit increases the default timeout for a test specified in
.testr.conf from 250 secs to 500 secs. The default build timeout
used for waiting for resource deletion is 400 secs. By using a test
timeout that was smaller than the build timeout some slow async
resource creation and deletions weren't completing before the test
was marked as failed for taking to long

Change-Id: Ia6292e68a8c3a0a0c03667a15f528c2ec6a5fbed
Partial-Bug: #1218585
"}]
commit_message:
Increase default test timeout for timeout fixture

This commit increases the default timeout for a test specified in
.testr.conf from 250 secs to 500 secs. The default build timeout
used for waiting for resource deletion is 400 secs. By using a test
timeout that was smaller than the build timeout some slow async
resource creation and deletions weren't completing before the test
was marked as failed for taking to long

Change-Id: Ia6292e68a8c3a0a0c03667a15f528c2ec6a5fbed
Partial-Bug: #1218585

validate the log line format string is valid for the given args.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-03 19:48:31.000000000', 'message': 'Update disagreements calculation.

Previously, this calculation only considered a positive vote when a core
team member gave a negative vote.  It now:

1) Also considers the opposite case: a negative vote overridden by a
positive vote

2) Considers vote order.  It only counts as a disagreement against a
reviewer if the core vote comes *after* the review in question.

Change-Id: Ia4423af05135d7dd26a6bdae667d54eae538f774
'}]
commit_message:
Update disagreements calculation.

Previously, this calculation only considered a positive vote when a core
team member gave a negative vote.  It now:

1) Also considers the opposite case: a negative vote overridden by a
positive vote

2) Considers vote order.  It only counts as a disagreement against a
reviewer if the core vote comes *after* the review in question.

Change-Id: Ia4423af05135d7dd26a6bdae667d54eae538f774

commit_message:
Rename Task.__call__ to Task.execute

We'd like library interface to be nice and simple, which implies that
it does not involve too many underscores. Also 'execute' matches with
'revert' nicely.

Suggested-by: Anastasia Karpinska <akarpinska@griddynamics.com>
Change-Id: Iea72e6230a32665b4236a1e7d1dcc41bd56d0418

commit_message:
Disable neutron quotas when using fake virt driver

Nova's fake virt driver, can be used to do scale testing, so when using
it disable neutron's quota limits.

Change-Id: I9ce995079af04202179820777217ef294df71226

commit_message:
Enable query image by tag

This patch will enable Glance client to query images by user
defined tags.

Implement bp image-query-by-tag
Implement bp glance-client-v2

Change-Id: I6f54630c5b7c9c567d85485ad4289284e5486814

commit_message:
compute rpcapi 2.29 is not backwards compatible

patch 6fcf4133b49cfefa77151937dec4db097a85c349 which added compute
rpcapi version 2.29 does not provide any backwards compatibility.

Fix this issue with 'self.can_send_version'

Fix bug 1217068

Change-Id: Idc49040b712058aab8d3ed769bdf18bdc0a4f067

'}, {'created': '2013-08-15 17:39:56.000000000', 'message': "Make compute_api use Service and ComputeNode objects

This converts compute_api (and associated nova-api and test code)
to use Service and ComputeNode objects for their work.

Note the removal of the nova.db import from compute/api.py.
There is still a chunk of code that uses self.db, but it's
progress.

Related to blueprint compute-api-objects

Change-Id: I7d0b4c0d02559ec16b35dd38278cdf738e0fda6c
"}, {'created': '2013-08-15 19:07:11.000000000', 'message': "Make compute_api use Service and ComputeNode objects

commit_message:
Make compute_api use Service and ComputeNode objects

This converts compute_api (and associated nova-api and test code)
to use Service and ComputeNode objects for their work.

Note the removal of the nova.db import from compute/api.py.
There is still a chunk of code that uses self.db, but it's
progress.

Related to blueprint compute-api-objects

Change-Id: I7d0b4c0d02559ec16b35dd38278cdf738e0fda6c

commit_message:
Remove unused LOG variable in scenario tests

In some scenario tests, there are unused LOG variables.
This commit removes them and their 'import log' too.

Change-Id: I318fa5783ddb55796082963052ab73135a697988

There is a lot of new functionality added here with no tests, AFAICT. Tests should be provided before we merge this."}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2013-07-30 20:27:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Hi Dan, there are 9 new tests here. 

There's no new functionality here, just a replacement for the V1 API.

Beside that, the *utils code is only related to interaction with the os, as you probably recall we split the classes this way, putting all the logic in the *ops classes and the  os interaction in the *utils classes, which are simple wrappers around the WMI Api, which in turn are hard to fit in a traditional unit testing solution due to their dynamic nature.

If you have any suggestion, I'd be happy to consider it."}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2013-07-30 23:22:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-09-02 16:47:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 25: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(6 inline comments)

I am not keen on the level of shared code between v1 and v2 utils.

Would be interested what other cores think, but it would seem better to modify the v1 code a little to ensure there is a lot more code being shared between the two.

My prefered solution is to use a strategy pattern style where you provide an object that encapsulates all the version specific calls, and pass that into a single utils file, throwing NotImplemented for the v2 only stuff in the v1 object. You could make a stricter template pattern, with a base object, and a v1 and v2 subclass. Basically, I don't really like inheritance that does not follow: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liskov_substitution_principle"}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2013-09-02 17:38:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 25: (5 inline comments)

I don't see where we are not following the Liskov principle. Th idea behind the design of the V1 and V2 classes was exactly to make instances of V1 replaceable with V2, so the semantic has been respected in all the methods.

Can you please point out examples of where we don't follow it?

About templates, as you probably noticed we make an extensive usage of this pattern."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-09-02 17:51:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 25:

Yeah, sorry, I got that wrong, you can substitute v1 for v2.

I think I got fixated on v2 being able to do stuff v1 can't do, my bad.

Its just the code duplication, and was just thinking up ways to reduce the code duplication without the template methods getting too crazy.

I guess its just messy, hence the code has to be a bit messy at this layer. Ah well."}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2013-09-02 18:13:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25: (1 inline comment)

I lost behind one comment answer, sorry.'}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2013-09-02 18:42:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 26.'}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2013-09-02 19:04:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 27.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-02 19:29:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-22 15:13:09.000000000', 'message': 'Adds support for Hyper-V WMI V2 namespace

Blueprint: hyper-v-wmi-v2

The Hyper-V APIs are mainly based on WMI. The original 2008 Hyper-V
release introduced the "root\virtualization" namespace which got superseded
in Hyper-V Server / Windows Server 2012 by the "root\virtualization\v2"
namespace (referred as V2 in the sources).

Features introduced in 2012, inclucing as an example live migration and VHDX
support are available via the V2 namespace only.

Furthermore, the original namespace has been dropped in the upcoming
Hyper-V 2012 R2 (currently available in preview), which means that the
Grizzly code will not be compatible with it as is.

The Hyper-V driver is structured with a clear decoupling between OS
intraction classes (so called *utils modules and classes) and the driver's
business logic (e.g.: *ops modules and classes).

This allows to provide an implementatios of the V2 API without impacting on
the rest of the drivers's code, with the addition of a factory module to
instantiate the proper version of the *utils classes: the original "V1" ones
for versions of the OS predating 2012 and the newer "V2" ones starting from
Hyper-V 2012 (Windows kernel version 6.2).

Unit tests have been added for the factoty functions.

Change-Id: I5246bdd33ee8e1b607bbf00b748225e933aa417a
'}, {'created': '2013-07-22 18:15:14.000000000', 'message': 'Adds support for Hyper-V WMI V2 namespace

Furthermore, the original namespace has been dropped in the upcoming
Hyper-V 2012 R2 (currently available in preview), which means that the

The Hyper-V driver is structured with a clear decoupling between OS
intraction classes (so called *utils modules and classes) and the driver's

This allows to provide an implementatios of the V2 API without impacting on

instantiate the proper version of the *utils classes: the original "V1" ones
for versions of the OS predating 2012 and the newer "V2" ones starting from

Unit tests have been added for the factoty functions.

Change-Id: I5246bdd33ee8e1b607bbf00b748225e933aa417a
'}, {'created': '2013-07-22 18:44:36.000000000', 'message': 'Adds support for Hyper-V WMI V2 namespace

Blueprint: hyper-v-wmi-v2

The Hyper-V APIs are mainly based on WMI. The original 2008 Hyper-V
release introduced the "root\virtualization" namespace which got
superseded in Hyper-V Server / Windows Server 2012 by the
"root\virtualization\v2" namespace (referred as V2 in the sources).

Features introduced in 2012, inclucing as an example live migration
and VHDX
support are available via the V2 namespace only.

Furthermore, the original namespace has been dropped in the upcoming
Hyper-V 2012 R2 (currently available in preview), which means that
the Grizzly code will not be compatible with it as is.

The Hyper-V driver is structured with a clear decoupling between OS
intraction classes (so called *utils modules and classes) and the
driver's business logic (e.g.: *ops modules and classes).

This allows to provide an implementatios of the V2 API without
impacting on the rest of the drivers's code, with the addition of a
factory module to instantiate the proper version of the *utils
classes: the original "V1" ones for versions of the OS predating
2012 and the newer "V2" ones starting from Hyper-V 2012 (Windows
kernel version 6.2).

Unit tests have been added for the factoty functions.

Change-Id: I5246bdd33ee8e1b607bbf00b748225e933aa417a
'}, {'created': '2013-07-22 18:47:38.000000000', 'message': 'Adds support for Hyper-V WMI V2 namespace

Blueprint: hyper-v-wmi-v2

The Hyper-V APIs are mainly based on WMI. The original 2008 Hyper-V
release introduced the "root\virtualization" namespace which got
superseded in Hyper-V Server / Windows Server 2012 by the
"root\virtualization\v2" namespace (referred as V2 in the sources).

Features introduced in 2012, inclucing as an example live migration
and VHDX
support are available via the V2 namespace only.

Furthermore, the original namespace has been dropped in the upcoming
Hyper-V 2012 R2 (currently available in preview), which means that
the Grizzly code will not be compatible with it as is.

The Hyper-V driver is structured with a clear decoupling between OS
intraction classes (so called *utils modules and classes) and the
driver's business logic (e.g.: *ops modules and classes).

This allows to provide an implementatios of the V2 API without
impacting on the rest of the drivers's code, with the addition of a
factory module to instantiate the proper version of the *utils
classes: the original "V1" ones for versions of the OS predating
2012 and the newer "V2" ones starting from Hyper-V 2012 (Windows
kernel version 6.2).

Unit tests have been added for the factoty functions.

Change-Id: I5246bdd33ee8e1b607bbf00b748225e933aa417a

impacting the rest of the driver's code, based on the previously

predating 2012 and the newer "V2" ones starting from Hyper-V 2012
(Windows kernel version 6.2).

Blueprint: hyper-v-wmi-v2

The Hyper-V APIs are mainly based on WMI. The original 2008 Hyper-V
release introduced the "root\virtualization" namespace which got
superseded in Hyper-V Server / Windows Server 2012 by the
"root\virtualization\v2" namespace (referred as V2 in the sources).

Features introduced in 2012, including as an example live migration
and VHDX support are available via the V2 namespace only.

Furthermore, the original namespace has been dropped in the upcoming
Hyper-V 2012 R2 (currently available in preview), which means that
the Grizzly code will not be compatible with it as is.

The Hyper-V driver is structured with a clear decoupling between OS
interaction classes (so called *utils modules and classes) and the
driver's business logic (e.g.: *ops modules and classes).

This allows us to provide an implementation of the V2 API without
impacting the rest of the driver's code, based on the previously
included utilsfactory module to instantiate the proper version of
the *utils classes: the original "V1" ones for versions of the OS
predating 2012 and the newer "V2" ones starting from Hyper-V 2012
(Windows kernel version 6.2).

Unit tests have been added for the relevant factory functions.

Change-Id: I5246bdd33ee8e1b607bbf00b748225e933aa417a

The Hyper-V APIs are mainly based on WMI. The original 2008 Hyper-V
release introduced the "root\virtualization" namespace which got
superseded in Hyper-V Server / Windows Server 2012 by the
"root\virtualization\v2" namespace (referred as V2 in the sources).

Features introduced in 2012, including as an example live migration
and VHDX support are available via the V2 namespace only.

Furthermore, the original namespace has been dropped in the upcoming
Hyper-V 2012 R2 (currently available in preview), which means that
the Grizzly code will not be compatible with it as is.

The Hyper-V driver is structured with a clear decoupling between OS
interaction classes (so called *utils modules and classes) and the
driver's business logic (e.g.: *ops modules and classes).

This allows us to provide an implementation of the V2 API without
impacting the rest of the driver's code, based on the previously
included utilsfactory module to instantiate the proper version of
the *utils classes: the original "V1" ones for versions of the OS
predating 2012 and the newer "V2" ones starting from Hyper-V 2012
(Windows kernel version 6.2).

Hyper-V previous V1 APIs can be forced by setting the following option
in the hyperv section to true. The default is false.

commit_message:
Adds support for Hyper-V WMI V2 namespace

Blueprint: hyper-v-wmi-v2

The Hyper-V APIs are mainly based on WMI. The original 2008 Hyper-V
release introduced the "root\virtualization" namespace which got
superseded in Hyper-V Server / Windows Server 2012 by the
"root\virtualization\v2" namespace (referred as V2 in the sources).

Features introduced in 2012, including as an example live migration
and VHDX support are available via the V2 namespace only.

Furthermore, the original namespace has been dropped in the upcoming
Hyper-V 2012 R2 (currently available in preview), which means that
the Grizzly code will not be compatible with it as is.

The Hyper-V driver is structured with a clear decoupling between OS
interaction classes (so called *utils modules and classes) and the
driver's business logic (e.g.: *ops modules and classes).

This allows us to provide an implementation of the V2 API without
impacting the rest of the driver's code, based on the previously
included utilsfactory module to instantiate the proper version of
the *utils classes: the original "V1" ones for versions of the OS
predating 2012 and the newer "V2" ones starting from Hyper-V 2012
(Windows kernel version 6.2).

Hyper-V previous V1 APIs can be forced by setting the following option
in the hyperv section to true. The default is false.

force_hyperv_utils_v1=false

Unit tests have been added for the relevant factory functions.

DocImpact
Change-Id: I5246bdd33ee8e1b607bbf00b748225e933aa417a

commit_message:
db2 distinct call results are different from mongodb call

when pymongo call distinct against a collection, the results are
different between db2 and mongodb. Need to write different code
to make sure jenkins test which is uses mongo and db2 both will
work.

Change-Id: I714c85f840a7e906ab76130cab214249c6ee0cf3

'}, {'created': '2013-08-09 08:54:17.000000000', 'message': 'Add scheduler support for PCI passthrough

PCI tracker update the PCI stats infomation which provide a abstract
resouce view to the scheduler.

stack client request the pci devices via the alias, which convert to
pci request. PCI passthrough filter check the PCI stats per the reqeust
of the instance, given the schedule result.

bp:pci-passthrough-base

Change-Id: I0ede4caefab8b22126d0c8b9293f023aa4780e36

commit_message:
Add scheduler support for PCI passthrough

PCI tracker updates the PCI stats information which provide an abstract
resource view to the scheduler

Openstack clients request PCI devices using PCI aliases, which are
converted to PCI requests. The PCI passthrough filter checks the PCI stats
for nodes that can satisfy the request of the instance, and gives the
schedule result.

bp:pci-passthrough-base

Change-Id: I0ede4caefab8b22126d0c8b9293f023aa4780e36
Signed-off-by: Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com>
Signed-off-by: Yunhong Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-03 13:05:15.000000000', 'message': "Fix errors in volume usage audit script

The snapshot_get_active_by_window DB query was returning snapshots
where we couldn't access the related volume object. This was due to
a) the volume not been loaded and the join failing due to detached
session object.
and b) the related volume was deleted so it didn't show return from
the join

Fixes bug: 1220140

Change-Id: I0de993ba0ca482fa9ab80d4d5cdb0ff5cc8e4d7a
"}]
commit_message:
Fix errors in volume usage audit script

The snapshot_get_active_by_window DB query was returning snapshots
where we couldn't access the related volume object. This was due to
a) the volume not been loaded and the join failing due to detached
session object.
and b) the related volume was deleted so it didn't show return from
the join

Fixes bug: 1220140

Change-Id: I0de993ba0ca482fa9ab80d4d5cdb0ff5cc8e4d7a

encryption choice field for volumes.  However, this choice field uses

commit_message:
Remove encryption option for volumes

Change Idb6a923f (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/21264/) added an
encryption choice field for volumes.  However, this choice field uses
volume metadata rather than volume type to denote an encrypted volume.
This option is removed in this patch, since the existing volume type
field should be used instead.

Change-Id: I730b4ffc26f391065943cb0d135ceac113cb6754
Implements: blueprint volume-encryption-field

and tab text based on "required" classname.
The current indicator is based on review with horizon UX
people and can be customized easily.

commit_message:
Implement required field indicator

Change Horizon's use of forms to set 'required' css class for required fields.
Change template _form_fields.html to include Django field classes in order
to honor above setting.
Also changed horizon workflow to set "required" class on tabs of steps
that contain required fields.

Horizon CSS appends an asterisk after the field label
and tab text based on "required" classname.
The current indicator is based on review with horizon UX
people and can be customized easily.

Change-Id: I03261328d70abcefd13f609088ccb4d58ef30067
Implements: blueprint required-fields

commit_message:
Scheduler rpcapi 2.9 is not backwards compatible

Patch 552693e4ad51291c8bfd28cd1939ed3609f6eeac which added scheduler
rpcapi version 2.9 does not provide any backwards compatibility.

This patch adds the check using 'self.can_send_version', and falls
back to the latest Grizzly compatible version if it the version is
capped.

Also takes the opportunity to make the docstring more consistent in the
scheduler rpcapi SchedulerAPI class.

Closes-bug: #1220112

Change-Id: I5a1e08c1066cae00d47def45f7b87846f679cbbe

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-24 09:42:36.000000000', 'message': 'test failure induced by reading system config file

run run_tests.sh or tox to test the glance code, it will get
following failure:
test_get_bind_addr_default_value
test_get_path_non_exist

Analysis
--------
The root cause is resided in "glance/tests/unit/api/test_cmd.py".
In TestGlanceApiCmd.setUp, the sys.argv is overrided to ['glance-api'].
Since sys.argv is "global" variable, and this test entry it run
firstly by nosetests while running tests in "glance/tests/unit"(since
nosetests search test items alphabetically), the other test entries
will inherit the sys.argv value ['glance-api']. Finally the system
config file "/etc/glance/glance-api.conf" is read in "setUp" via
oslo.config.cfg:ConfigOpts.__call__ -> _pre_setup -> find_config_files.
CONF.bind_port and CONF.bind_host is set to the value reading from
system config file: /etc/glance/glance-api.conf.

A simplied call backtrace:
TestGlanceApiCmd.setUp -->  sys.argv = ['glance-api']
 ->JSONRequestDeserializerTest.setUp
  ->glance/common/config.py:parse_args
   ->oslo.config.cfg:ConfigOpts.__call__
    ->CONF.bind_port CONF.bind_host is set

wsgi.get_bind_addr() will read the CONF.bind_port and CONF.bind_host
to return value. if system config file is not read, CONF.bind_host
is set to "0.0.0.0", CONF.bind_port is not set. wsgi.get_bind_addr()
will return the expected value. This is the reason that individual
test of test_get_bind_addr_default_value got passed, but failed while
testing all.

The failure of test_get_path_non_exist is induced by same reason.

Test case should clear up the setting in tearDown(), especially the
"global" setting, e.g. sys.argv.

Solution
--------
The solution is simple:
In class TestGlanceApiCmd, add a private variable to backup the
sys.argv in setUp(), and restore it in tearDown().

Test method
-----------
$ ./run_tests.sh

$ tox -evenv -- nosetests \
--tests=glance.tests.unit.common.test_config:TestPasteApp

tox -evenv -- nosetests
--tests=glance.tests.unit.common.test_wsgi:JSONRequestDeserializerTest

Fixes Bug #1204186

Change-Id: I2dac8e506fa794d1faa9509258936d78e2f981d8
'}]
commit_message:
test failure induced by reading system config file

run run_tests.sh or tox to test the glance code, it will get
following failure:
test_get_bind_addr_default_value
test_get_path_non_exist

Analysis
--------
The root cause is resided in "glance/tests/unit/api/test_cmd.py".
In TestGlanceApiCmd.setUp, the sys.argv is overrided to ['glance-api'].
Since sys.argv is "global" variable, and this test entry it run
firstly by nosetests while running tests in "glance/tests/unit"(since
nosetests search test items alphabetically), the other test entries
will inherit the sys.argv value ['glance-api']. Finally the system
config file "/etc/glance/glance-api.conf" is read in "setUp" via
oslo.config.cfg:ConfigOpts.__call__ -> _pre_setup -> find_config_files.
CONF.bind_port and CONF.bind_host is set to the value reading from
system config file: /etc/glance/glance-api.conf.

A simplied call backtrace:
TestGlanceApiCmd.setUp -->  sys.argv = ['glance-api']
 ->JSONRequestDeserializerTest.setUp
  ->glance/common/config.py:parse_args
   ->oslo.config.cfg:ConfigOpts.__call__
    ->CONF.bind_port CONF.bind_host is set

wsgi.get_bind_addr() will read the CONF.bind_port and CONF.bind_host
to return value. if system config file is not read, CONF.bind_host
is set to "0.0.0.0", CONF.bind_port is not set. wsgi.get_bind_addr()
will return the expected value. This is the reason that individual
test of test_get_bind_addr_default_value got passed, but failed while
testing all.

The failure of test_get_path_non_exist is induced by same reason.

Test case should clear up the setting in tearDown(), especially the
"global" setting, e.g. sys.argv.

Solution
--------
The solution is simple:
In class TestGlanceApiCmd, add a private variable to backup the
sys.argv in setUp(), and restore it in tearDown().

Test method
-----------
$ ./run_tests.sh

$ tox -evenv -- nosetests \
--tests=glance.tests.unit.common.test_config:TestPasteApp

tox -evenv -- nosetests
--tests=glance.tests.unit.common.test_wsgi:JSONRequestDeserializerTest

Fixes Bug #1204186

Change-Id: I2dac8e506fa794d1faa9509258936d78e2f981d8

Fixed the neutron router-gateway-set command regression:
"neutron router-gateway-set <router> <public-net>"
is failing for non-admin users.

Changed the behavior to pass the enable_snat attribute to
the server only when the --disable-snat option is specified.

bug 1209027

Change-Id: Iec55a17ed7966ee15bf05982d98540fe6884fa20

commit_message:
neutron router-gateway-set failed for non-admin users

Fixed the neutron router-gateway-set command regression:
"neutron router-gateway-set <router> <public-net>"
is failing for non-admin users.

Changed the behavior to pass the enable_snat attribute to
the server only when the --disable-snat option is specified.

bug 1209027

Change-Id: Iec55a17ed7966ee15bf05982d98540fe6884fa20

commit_message:
Try to scope token for all available projects

When scoping fails on the first project, continue trying until
a scoped token can be acquired.

Change-Id: I2827595423d5be0f5be9a24eded2a63ab7771ca7
Fixes: bug 1212748

commit_message:
VMware image clone strategy settings and defaults.

The VMwareAPI driver code currently spawns all virtual machines
copying the disks using a linked-clone strategy by default.
The VMwareAPI also offers a "full clone" strategy. This patch
makes the following changes and improvements.

* default clone strategy to "full clone"
* allow images to specify if they are "linked_clone" or not.

For technical discussion on the clone strategies and their trade-offs
see: https://www.vmware.com/support/ws5/doc/ws_clone_typeofclone.html

Change-Id: Icce02ea538168489f4ee51502c41a7ce66d3d2ee
Blueprint: vmware-image-clone-strategy

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-03 17:12:15.000000000', 'message': 'Nova boot fails when vCenter has multiple ESX hosts.

The nova driver for vCenter fails when there are multiple hosts
that are co-equal in the vCenter inventory. This means there is
no logical default server to use and vCenter fails to place the
VM. This can be caused by multiple DataCenters, multiple clusters
(without a specific cluster specified), or a cluster that does
not have DRS enabled.

fixes bug 1180044

Change-Id: I88b56ea409f8e85e63d06c4ffd7e66ea16e722c9
'}]
commit_message:
Nova boot fails when vCenter has multiple ESX hosts.

The nova driver for vCenter fails when there are multiple hosts
that are co-equal in the vCenter inventory. This means there is
no logical default server to use and vCenter fails to place the
VM. This can be caused by multiple DataCenters, multiple clusters
(without a specific cluster specified), or a cluster that does
not have DRS enabled.

fixes bug 1180044

Change-Id: I88b56ea409f8e85e63d06c4ffd7e66ea16e722c9

commit_message:
VNC console does not work with VCDriver

Introduces get_vnc_console_vcenter as a way to get
a modified vnc_console object that connects to the
ESXi host underneath vCenter control.

* adds new fake classes for testing
* documents classes, methods & API logic

fixes bug: #1178369

Change-Id: I48430cb9bc9615e02ca9af235f97853f3f0bdafd

commit_message:
fix broken WSDL logic

vSphere driver incorrectly assumes that a WSDL is locally required.
A local WSDL is only needed as a work-around for certain situations.

Fixes bug 1171215

Change-Id: Id8c5fc104c244ba768c58b97afdc26703c5c42ac

commit_message:
fix broken WSDL logic

vSphere driver incorrectly assumes that a WSDL is locally required.
A local WSDL is only needed as a work-around for certain situations.

Fixes bug 1171215

cherry picked from commit cf3cc74fcb65de3c59f98db001267e05ae405186

Change-Id: I1cc81d96e263ad586b903a74dc9d5c602d475dc9

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-18 17:37:27.000000000', 'message': 'No support for double nested 64 bit guest using VCDriver

64bit instances launched on ESX via the VCDriver will not
support running 64bit guests. There is an option that can
be passed during the vmx creation that will allow for this
to happen. This is very useful if you want to run hypervisors
 (esx, kvm) on top of ESX and then run 64bit VMs on top of
those hypervisors.

Fixes bug 1192256

Change-Id: Id6eb224c97569737cbb41f1b64f61805e1df004e
'}]
commit_message:
No support for double nested 64 bit guest using VCDriver

64bit instances launched on ESX via the VCDriver will not
support running 64bit guests. There is an option that can
be passed during the vmx creation that will allow for this
to happen. This is very useful if you want to run hypervisors
 (esx, kvm) on top of ESX and then run 64bit VMs on top of
those hypervisors.

Fixes bug 1192256

Change-Id: Id6eb224c97569737cbb41f1b64f61805e1df004e

commit_message:
Fix VMware Hyper can't honor hw_vif_model image property.

Support setting instance vif model through image property,
change default vif model to e1000. Available vif model options
for VMware Hyperv is "VirtualE1000, VirtualPCNet32, VirtualVmxnet".

DocImpact
Fix bug #1183192

Change-Id: I3a98bc26df7e2252bf043a71acbba2a158e213b8

commit_message:
Fix VMwareVCdriver reporting incorrect stats

fix bug #1180779

VMware nova compute drivers VMwareESXDriver and VMwareVCDriver
currently report stats for the column local_gb in MB instead of in GB
The fix would be to modify vmwareapi/host.py to ensure the values
reported for disk space are calculated in GB instead of MB.
Fix is done by further dividing the existing MB value by 1024 to
convert to GB.
The unit tests to check for capacity and freespace have been modified
to check for GB.

Change-Id: I0610047ee2bddefe0ccb46568c0f48de4c0941af

vSphere driver incorrectly assumes that a WSDL is locally required.
A local WSDL is only needed as a work-around for certain situations.

Fixes bug 1171215

Change-Id: Id8c5fc104c244ba768c58b97afdc26703c5c42ac
(cherry picked from commit cf3cc74fcb65de3c59f98db001267e05ae405186)
'}]
commit_message:
fix broken WSDL logic

vSphere driver incorrectly assumes that a WSDL is locally required.
A local WSDL is only needed as a work-around for certain situations.

Fixes bug 1171215

Change-Id: Id8c5fc104c244ba768c58b97afdc26703c5c42ac
(cherry picked from commit cf3cc74fcb65de3c59f98db001267e05ae405186)

'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-02 20:30:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (4 inline comments)

A couple of comments, and one question about how this works. I'll admit to not knowing a lot about the existing extension system, so please point me at docs if they are really basic and covered somewhere (the link to extension docs at http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/#api-extensions just points to the API doc site, which doesn't seem to have anything about writing extensions)."}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-05-03 07:04:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (4 inline comments)

Hi Doug,

Thanks you very much for looking over the patch. AFAIK there is no documentation on how to the current extension framework works or how to write extensions. I think people just end up looking at existing extensions (there is an example foxinsocks one which doesn't seem to work properly anymore) and basing theirs on whatever most closely matches what they are trying to do. So we've ended probably ended up with quite a few bad habits along the way as people don't always exactly understand how things work.

I looked around for documentation myself for this rework and ended up having to just read the code to try to work out what is going on.

Decent developer documentation is something I definitely want in place for the new framework before the end of the havana cycle."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2013-05-03 20:22:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

One small NIT inline'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-05-04 09:30:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi Christopher,

I have one question.
After applying this extension framework, will both v2 extensions' code(ex. [..]/contrib/fixed_ips.py) and v3 extensions' code(ex. [..]/plugins/fixed_ips.py) exist?

I am working for API validation framework, and I feel it is a good chance to apply the validation framework to Nova v3 API because compatibility issues don't happen.

In current my implementation of the validation framework, the validation works only if API method has its API schema.
If the implementation of v3 API methods is separated from the one of v2, it is easy to implement the validation framework only for v3 API.
We can implement the validation only for v3 API by adding @wsgi.validator() to v3 API method like https://review.openstack.org/#/c/25358/7/nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/aggregates.py."}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-05-04 15:52:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

Ken'ichi - I need to have a good look at your patch (was already on my TODO list since I saw the mailing list discussion), but it all sounds good. Yes the implementation of the v3 API will be completely separate so we can have the validation framework just for v3."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-05-05 14:27:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

Hi Christopher,

Thank you for quick response, and I'm glad to hear that the API methods of v3 are separated from the ones of v2.

also a small comment is inline."}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-05-06 00:04:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-05-06 04:42:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-06 05:29:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

(1 inline comment)

I think this looks good, though I'm not familiar with stevedore.

I can second Chris's earlier statement @Doug that there don't seem to be any docs about writing extensions. I wrote mine using core extensions as examples, looking at several of them and checking what's common to most. I like the idea of requiring derivation from the base class to give the needed guidance on what's needed for the extension to work.

I also used a second osapi_compute_extension flag in my config to be able to install my extensions apart from the nova tree to keep my custom additions organized. So I like that this approach allows extensions to live anywhere with a clean way using entry points."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-09 03:42:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-22 16:58:00.000000000', 'message': "API extensions framework for v3 API

This is the initial patch for the new extension framework to be used
by the Nova v3 API. It will only be used by v3 API extensions
and not v2 API extensions. v3 API extensions will only use this plugin
framework and will not be compatible with the old one.

- Sets up a /v3 url prefix
- Looks in an entry point namespace of nova.api.extensions
- The fixed_ips extensions is ported to /v3 as an example of
  a resource extensions. Required changes are very minor.
- None of the core has been ported in this patch, though
  the example extension works without it. The intent is
  to port the core code over as plugins as well. There will still
  be a conceptual core however I don't think we need a separate directory
  for core.

For an example as to how the framework works with controller extensions,
porting core code as plugins (extension registration) and removing extension
specific code from core code see here:

https://github.com/cyeoh/nova/tree/v3_api_extension_framework

It is not included in this initial patch as I wanted to keep this
one small and simple to make it easier to discuss. I am looking
for as much feedback as possible before things start to get
set in stone :-)

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-extension-framework

Change-Id: I88aa6353ad1d74cac51abbb6aac7274b1567485a
"}, {'created': '2013-05-02 05:53:03.000000000', 'message': "API extensions framework for v3 API

This is the initial patch for the new extension framework to be used
by the Nova v3 API. It will only be used by v3 API extensions
and not v2 API extensions. v3 API extensions will only use this plugin
framework and will not be compatible with the old one.

- Sets up a /v3 url prefix
- Looks in an entry point namespace of nova.api.extensions
- The fixed_ips extensions is ported to /v3 as an example of
  a resource extensions. Required changes are very minor.
- Drops updated field from extensions, replaced with version field
- Ports tests for fixed_ips extension
- None of the core has been ported in this patch, though
  the example extension works without it. The intent is
  to port the core code over as plugins as well. There will still
  be a conceptual core however I don't think we need a separate directory
  for core.

This is the first of a series of patches to add support for the
new extension framework. Future direction including support
for controller extensions, removal of extension code in core
code etc can be seen here:

https://github.com/cyeoh/nova/tree/v3_api_extension_framework

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-extension-framework

Change-Id: I88aa6353ad1d74cac51abbb6aac7274b1567485a

  be a conceptual core however I don't think we need a separate directory
  for core.

for controller extensions, removal of extension code in core
code etc can be seen here:

https://github.com/cyeoh/nova/tree/v3_api_extension_framework

commit_message:
API extensions framework for v3 API

This is the initial patch for the new extension framework to be used
by the Nova v3 API. It will only be used by v3 API extensions
and not v2 API extensions. v3 API extensions will only use this plugin
framework and will not be compatible with the old one.

- Sets up a /v3 url prefix
- Looks in an entry point namespace of nova.api.extensions
- The fixed_ips extensions is ported to /v3 as an example of
  a resource extensions. Required changes are very minor.
- All extensions must derive from the V3APIExtensionBase class
- Drops updated field from extensions, replaced with version field
- Ports tests for fixed_ips extension
- None of the core has been ported in this patch, though
  the example extension works without it. The intent is
  to port the core code over as plugins as well. There will still
  be a conceptual core however I don't think we need a separate directory
  for core.

This is the first of a series of patches to add support for the
new extension framework. Future direction including support
for controller extensions, removal of extension code in core
code etc can be seen here:

https://github.com/cyeoh/nova/tree/v3_api_extension_framework

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-extension-framework

Change-Id: I88aa6353ad1d74cac51abbb6aac7274b1567485a

Change-Id: I30029b9b74187ace66de4f4bb6620e8a88bd18f6

commit_message:
Remove orc/oac from heat-cfntools dependency chain

With os-collect-config, we no longer use cfn-hup to run
os-refresh-config. Without that need, we no longer need os-apply-config to
configure cfn-hup.

Change-Id: I30029b9b74187ace66de4f4bb6620e8a88bd18f6

commit_message:
Fix row striping when sorting table data

This will ensure that table rows alternate colors after changing
the sort order of a column

Fixes Bug: 1218058

Change-Id: Ie80f8365e22662781015cbb5c158fdc411e94037

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-02 09:00:41.000000000', 'message': 'Rerun os-collect-config if config changed

Keep a hash of the config file for os-colect-config and if it changes
during a failed run then rerun immediately(without sleep), effectively
causing new nodes to be ready 5 minutes earlier.

Because the cfn credentials are placed into os-collect-config.conf by
os-apply-config and are not in place the first time os-collect-config is
run, the first run of os-collect-config results in error, o-c-c then
sleeps for 5 minutes before running successfully the second time.

Fixes bug #1219186

Change-Id: I090de7a3d84e0ea342f1a422646c0c455eb37f4a
'}, {'created': '2013-09-03 16:04:09.000000000', 'message': 'Rerun os-collect-config if config changed

Keep a hash of the config file for os-collect-config and if it changes
during a failed run then rerun immediately(without sleep), effectively
causing new nodes to be ready 5 minutes earlier.

Because the cfn credentials are placed into os-collect-config.conf by
os-apply-config and are not in place the first time os-collect-config is
run, the first run of os-collect-config results in error, o-c-c then
sleeps for 5 minutes before running successfully the second time.

Fixes bug #1219186

Change-Id: I090de7a3d84e0ea342f1a422646c0c455eb37f4a
'}]
commit_message:
Rerun os-collect-config if config changed

Keep a hash of the config file for os-collect-config and if it changes
during a failed run then rerun immediately(without sleep), effectively
causing new nodes to be ready 5 minutes earlier.

Because the cfn credentials are placed into os-collect-config.conf by
os-apply-config and are not in place the first time os-collect-config is
run, the first run of os-collect-config results in error, o-c-c then
sleeps for 5 minutes before running successfully the second time.

Fixes bug #1219186

Change-Id: I090de7a3d84e0ea342f1a422646c0c455eb37f4a

[{'created': '2013-09-03 05:04:13.000000000', 'message': "Switch devtest images to only include o-c-c

Up until now we've been including heat-cfntools, which was somewhat
erroneously configuring cfn-hup to run os-refresh-config. The dependency
on os-refresh-config was in turn bringing in os-collect-config, which is
actually what the tripleo Heat templates expect now.

Change-Id: Ied4db80c4de9f3e7cbf629bec297766321053288
"}]
commit_message:
Switch devtest images to only include o-c-c

Up until now we've been including heat-cfntools, which was somewhat
erroneously configuring cfn-hup to run os-refresh-config. The dependency
on os-refresh-config was in turn bringing in os-collect-config, which is
actually what the tripleo Heat templates expect now.

Change-Id: Ied4db80c4de9f3e7cbf629bec297766321053288

commit_message:
Add os-block-device-mapping to v3 API

Create a new v3 extension called os-block-device-mapping to handle
the block devices specified on server creation. This extension was
os-block-device-mapping-v2-boot in the old API.

Only the new block device mapping syntax has been ported although the
old one can still be used with v2 API.

blueprint: improve-block-device-handling

Change-Id: I898ae56539c6101680983d1eca4bce6d92bd5ce6

commit_message:
Basic support of Ironic

Ironic is an OpenStack project than brings a
separate service for baremetal provisioning.
Currently Ironic is in incubation but it needs
to have basic support in devstack to provide
automatic deployment testing.

Change-Id: Ide65a1379fa207a6c8b2c7d9a4f9c874b10fd9ba

commit_message:
Cleanup cache layer tests

Simple cleanup of keystone/tests/test_cache.py.  Added the following
tests:

* Global Should Cache Toggle
* Configure Non-CacheRegion object raises Validation Error
* Cache Debug Proxy doesn't mangle data / raise exceptions
* Cache Noop Backend, in-fact, does nothing.

Isolation proxy un-used methods removed.

closes-bug: 1218743
Change-Id: Id980a9bff554c72a02461cecbcb533466225a701

subject: updating tempurl,formpost and the associated signature generator tools to use keystone based accesskey/secretkey for validation. implementing blueprints tempURL and formPOST middleware change
messages:
[{'account_id': 860, 'date': '2013-08-27 17:14:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (8 inline comments)

It's not clear to me how this would pass the string to sign to the signature validator. 

I'm also confused by the flow of control through __call__(). One problem throughout is that you gave taken functions that currently return the secret key *value*, but instead make them return either the *value* (X-Account-Meta data) or the *id* (Keystone).


I wonder is it worth thinking"}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-09-03 16:02:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

I agree with Donagh. We should be using a configurable (filter) property to indication *how* to validate the signature. It really doesn't matter where the access key ID is specified."}]

commit_message:
updating tempurl,formpost and the associated signature generator
tools to use keystone based accesskey/secretkey for validation.
implementing blueprints tempURL and formPOST middleware change

Change-Id: I270d658016ec672342d2dcda54153c5e7ae2be07

commit_message:
added Network Agents to System Info panel

Added a new tab to the System Info panel showing all Network Agents.

fixes bug #1204375

Change-Id: I9c23105dde8528749275aba70065384dec354fb7

commit_message:
Export portinfo thru portbinding ext in NEC plugin

blueprint nec-port-binding

* Add host-id support in port-binding extension.
* Expose portinfo thourgh binding:profile attr in a port.
  portinfo is a mapping between neutron port id and OpenFlow switch
  physical information (datapath_id and port_no)

It changes the following in portinfo db model
* Add cascade on delete to delete an associated portinfo
  when deleting the port.
* Use joined query for portinfo model to retrieve an associated
  portinfo when querying a port.

Change-Id: Id88d93dc0770a1290714436324b1b53c0b023eeb

commit_message:
Check ephemeral and swap size in the API

Validate that ephemeral and swap disks passed in trough the API are
within size limits for the given instance type. The validation is done
in the API layer.

Closes-bug #1218977

Change-Id: I96c6e651e4b221313c39dfc41e79d536585fb955

supported by Heat with unit tests.
